Hydrodynamic fluctuations and long-time tails in a fluid on an anisotropic background

Ashish Shukla ashukla@perimeterinstitute.ca Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics, 31 Caroline Street North, Waterloo, Ontario N2L 2Y5, Canada
Abstract

The effective low-energy late-time description of many body systems near thermal equilibrium provided by classical hydrodynamics in terms of dissipative transport phenomena receives important corrections once the effects of stochastic fluctuations are taken into account. One such physical effect is the occurrence of long-time power law tails in correlation functions of conserved currents. In the hydrodynamic regime ùê§ ‚Üí 0 ‚Üí ùê§ 0 {\bf k}\rightarrow 0 bold_k ‚Üí 0 this amounts to non-analytic dependence of the correlation functions on the frequency œâ ùúî \omega italic_œâ . In this article, we consider a relativistic fluid with a conserved global U ( 1 ) ùëà 1 U(1) italic_U ( 1 ) charge in the presence of a strong background magnetic field, and compute the long-time tails in correlation functions of the stress tensor. The presence of the magnetic field renders the system anisotropic. In the absence of the magnetic field, there are three out-of-equilibrium transport parameters that arise at the first order in the hydrodynamic derivative expansion, all of which are dissipative. In the presence of a background magnetic field, there are ten independent out-of-equilibrium transport parameters at the first order, three of which are non-dissipative and the rest are dissipative. We provide the most general linearized equations about a given state of thermal equilibrium involving the various transport parameters in the presence of a magnetic field, and use them to compute the long-time tails for the fluid.

keywords:
Hydrodynamic fluctuations, Charged fluids, Magnetic fields, Non-analyticities, Long-time tails
arXiv:2101.10000
‚Ä† ‚Ä† journal: Nuclear Physics B

1 Introduction

Hydrodynamics provides an effective description of low-energy late-time dynamics of systems near thermal equilibrium. At long time scales, the evolution and relaxation of the system is governed by the dynamics of the conserved currents associated to the system, such as the energy-momentum tensor. In the hydrodynamic regime, the conserved currents can be expressed in an expansion in number of derivatives acting on the hydrodynamic variables, with transport parameters entering as coefficients of various terms in this expansion (see Kovtun:2012rj ; Jeon:2015dfa ; Romatschke:2017ejr for pedagogical reviews). These transport parameters capture important physical properties of the system under consideration, and can either be dissipative i.e.¬†lead to entropy production, or non-dissipative.

The equations of hydrodynamics are nothing but the conservation equations for the conserved currents of the system. A salient feature of the hydrodynamic equations is the fact that they are highly nonlinear in nature. The nonlinear terms give rise to interactions between the fluctuating hydrodynamic degrees of freedom. These interactions in turn have several important consequences for the dynamics of the system. One of these is the non-analytic dependence on frequency œâ ùúî \omega italic_œâ of the two-point correlation functions of the conserved currents of the system in the long wavelength limit ùê§ ‚Üí 0 ‚Üí ùê§ 0 {\bf k}\rightarrow 0 bold_k ‚Üí 0 . In real time, this translates to power-law dependence of correlation functions on time t ùë° t italic_t at late times, aptly called long-time tails POMEAU197563 ; Arnold:1997gh , as opposed to an exponential fall-off one would expect if there were no interactions. In particular, the value of the power-law exponent is independent of the microscopic details of the theory, and thus important macroscopic information can be extracted from the long-time tails, even for strongly coupled systems.

One way to think about the occurrence of fluctuations is to realize that hydrodynamics is a coarse grained macroscopic description of the system. The fluctuations that occur in the hydrodynamic degrees of freedom can thus be thought of arising as a consequence of integrating out the microscopic degrees of freedom, which may themselves have an inherent thermal randomness. This approach to hydrodynamic fluctuations, called stochastic hydrodynamics, models the fluctuations to be sourced by random microscopic currents and stresses, which are Gaussian correlated Landau1957 ; PhysRevA.8.423 ; RevModPhys.49.435 . More recently, an effective field theory (EFT) approach based on the Schwinger-Keldysh closed time path for non-equilibrium systems has been developed for studying fluctuating hydrodynamics, which takes into account the effects of fluctuations beyond the assumption of Gaussianity Crossley:2015evo ; Haehl:2015uoc ; Jensen:2017kzi . See Chen-Lin:2018kfl ; Jain:2020hcu ; lttsk for recent studies of analyticity properties of correlation functions and long-time tails in the Schwinger-Keldysh EFT approach.

In this paper, we initiate the study of long-time tails in a relativistic fluid with a global U ( 1 ) ùëà 1 U(1) italic_U ( 1 ) symmetry, in the presence of a strong background magnetic field. One motivation for computing these tails could be the dynamics of the quark-gluon plasma (QGP) produced in heavy ion collisions, where the magnetic fields produced in non-central collisions can reach magnitudes of the order 10 14 superscript 10 14 10^{14} 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 14 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Tesla Kharzeev:2007jp ; Skokov:2009qp ; Bzdak:2011yy . Our analysis will be similar in spirit to the ones in Arnold:1997gh ; Kovtun:2003vj , which in turn assume the fluctuations to be Gaussian in nature, just as in stochastic hydrodynamics. As pointed out in Kovtun:2003vj , in the small ùê§ ùê§ {\bf k} bold_k regime, the distribution of fluctuations is arbitrarily close to being Gaussian, with non-Gaussian contributions providing only sub-leading corrections to the leading long-time tails. With this in mind, we compute the linearized hydrodynamic equations about a given state of global thermal equilibrium for a relativistic fluid in the presence of a background magnetic field, and use them to compute the long-time tails in stress tensor correlation functions and their dependence on the magnetic field as well as some of the first-order transport parameters.

This article is organized as follows. In section 2 , we start by reviewing the properties of a charged fluid in thermal equilibrium in the presence of a strong background magnetic field. For a parity preserving fluid in four spacetime dimensions, which we shall be focusing on, there is one transport parameter in thermal equilibrium at one-derivative order, the magneto-vortical susceptibility M Œ© subscript ùëÄ Œ© M_{\Omega} italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . Out of equilibrium, there are ten more Hernandez:2017mch . These are the three non-equilibrium non-dissipative parameters: the two Hall viscosities Œ∑ ~ ‚üÇ , Œ∑ ~ ‚à• subscript ~ ùúÇ perpendicular-to subscript ~ ùúÇ parallel-to \tilde{\eta}_{\perp},\tilde{\eta}_{\parallel} over~ start_ARG italic_Œ∑ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over~ start_ARG italic_Œ∑ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , and one Hall conductivity œÉ ~ ~ ùúé \tilde{\sigma} over~ start_ARG italic_œÉ end_ARG , and seven dissipative parameters: the two electrical conductivities œÉ ‚üÇ , œÉ ‚à• subscript ùúé perpendicular-to subscript ùúé parallel-to \sigma_{\perp},\sigma_{\parallel} italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , the two shear viscosities Œ∑ ‚üÇ , Œ∑ ‚à• subscript ùúÇ perpendicular-to subscript ùúÇ parallel-to \eta_{\perp},\eta_{\parallel} italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , and four bulk viscosities Œ∂ 1 , Œ∂ 2 , Œ∑ 1 , Œ∑ 2 subscript ùúÅ 1 subscript ùúÅ 2 subscript ùúÇ 1 subscript ùúÇ 2 \zeta_{1},\zeta_{2},\eta_{1},\eta_{2} italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , of which only three are independent due to the Onsager relation 3 Œ∂ 2 ‚àí 6 Œ∑ 1 ‚àí 2 Œ∑ 2 = 0 3 subscript ùúÅ 2 6 subscript ùúÇ 1 2 subscript ùúÇ 2 0 3\zeta_{2}-6\eta_{1}-2\eta_{2}=0 3 italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 6 italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 2 italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 . We review the construction of the equilibrium generating functional up to first order in derivatives, and vary it with respect to the sources to obtain the associated energy-momentum tensor and the conserved current. In section 3 , we go beyond the assumption of thermal equilibrium, and include fluctuations about an equilibrium configuration. We write down the constitutive relations including non-equilibrium corrections, highlighting the role of various transport parameters that appear at this order. Subsequently, in section 4 , we construct the linearized hydrodynamic equations, and compute the retarded two-point correlation functions of the hydrodynamic degrees of freedom about a state of equilibrium, making use of linear response theory. Finally, in section 5 , we include nonlinear terms in the hydrodynamic constitutive relations, and compute the long-time tails in the correlation functions of the energy-momentum tensor. This requires us to make use of the symmetric correlation functions that follow from linear response theory. These can be obtained from the retarded correlation functions using the fluctuation-dissipation relation. We illustrate the dependence of the long-time tails on two of the many transport parameters that occur for the fluid on the anisotropic background: the shear viscosity Œ∑ ‚à• subscript ùúÇ parallel-to \eta_{\parallel} italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the bulk viscosity Œ∂ 1 subscript ùúÅ 1 \zeta_{1} italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . The paper ends with a discussion in section 6 .

Notation and conventions. ‚ÄîThe metric has signature ( ‚àí + + + ) (-+++) ( - + + + ) . Spacetime indices are denoted by Greek letters Œº , ŒΩ , ‚Ä¶ = ( 0 , 1 , 2 , 3 ) ùúá ùúà ‚Ä¶ 0 1 2 3 \mu,\nu,\ldots=(0,1,2,3) italic_Œº , italic_ŒΩ , ‚Ä¶ = ( 0 , 1 , 2 , 3 ) . Spatial indices are denoted by Latin letters i , j , ‚Ä¶ = ( 1 , 2 , 3 ) ùëñ ùëó ‚Ä¶ 1 2 3 i,j,\ldots=(1,2,3) italic_i , italic_j , ‚Ä¶ = ( 1 , 2 , 3 ) . Spatial vectors are denoted in boldface, e.g. ùê§ , ùê± ùê§ ùê± {\bf k,x} bold_k , bold_x etc. Scalar product of spatial vectors is denoted in boldface, e.g. ùê§ ‚ãÖ ùê± ‚ãÖ ùê§ ùê± {\bf k\cdot x} bold_k ‚ãÖ bold_x , whereas the Lorentz invariant inner product of four-vectors is denoted without boldface, e.g. A ‚ãÖ B ‚â° Œ∑ Œº ŒΩ A Œº B ŒΩ ‚ãÖ ùê¥ ùêµ subscript ùúÇ ùúá ùúà superscript ùê¥ ùúá superscript ùêµ ùúà A\cdot B\equiv\eta_{\mu\nu}A^{\mu}B^{\nu} italic_A ‚ãÖ italic_B ‚â° italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . 2 Thermal equilibrium in a strong magnetic field

When a system in thermal equilibrium is perturbed, it relaxes back to equilibrium via dynamical processes that are generically governed by two types of variables: slow and fast. The slow variables are typically associated with conserved quantities of the system, that can relax back only by physical transport, and thus govern the dynamics of the perturbed system over long time scales. The fast variables, on the other hand, are associated with non-conserved quantities, and can relax back to the new equilibrium state very quickly. Hydrodynamics captures the long-time low-energy behaviour of conserved quantities of the system, as the system relaxes back to thermal equilibrium after being perturbed.

Before jumping into hydrodynamics, we would like to better understand the state of thermal equilibrium itself. Mathematically, thermal equilibrium is quantified via the presence of a timelike vector V Œº superscript ùëâ ùúá V^{\mu} italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , which in the fluid rest frame takes the form V rest Œº = ( 1 , ùüé ) subscript superscript ùëâ ùúá rest 1 0 V^{\mu}_{\rm rest}=(1,{\bf 0}) italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_rest end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 , bold_0 ) . The intuitive fact that things in equilibrium do not change with time is imposed by the condition that the Lie derivative of the hydrodynamic variables as well as the sources with respect to V Œº superscript ùëâ ùúá V^{\mu} italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT vanishes. In fact, in thermal equilibrium, the hydrodynamic variables, which are the fluid four-velocity u Œº superscript ùë¢ ùúá u^{\mu} italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , temperature T ùëá T italic_T , and chemical potential Œº ùúá \mu italic_Œº , can be defined in terms of the vector V Œº superscript ùëâ ùúá V^{\mu} italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the sources as Banerjee:2012iz ; Jensen:2012jh

T = T 0 ‚àí V 2 , u Œº = V Œº ‚àí V 2 , Œº = V Œº A Œº + Œõ V ‚àí V 2 , formulae-sequence ùëá subscript ùëá 0 superscript ùëâ 2 formulae-sequence superscript ùë¢ ùúá superscript ùëâ ùúá superscript ùëâ 2 ùúá superscript ùëâ ùúá subscript ùê¥ ùúá subscript Œõ ùëâ superscript ùëâ 2 T=\frac{T_{0}}{\sqrt{-V^{2}}}\,,\quad u^{\mu}=\frac{V^{\mu}}{\sqrt{-V^{2}}}\,,\quad\mu=\frac{V^{\mu}A_{\mu}+\Lambda_{V}}{\sqrt{-V^{2}}}\,, italic_T = divide start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG - italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG , italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG - italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG , italic_Œº = divide start_ARG italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_Œõ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG - italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG , (1)

where V 2 ‚â° g Œº ŒΩ V Œº V ŒΩ superscript ùëâ 2 subscript ùëî ùúá ùúà superscript ùëâ ùúá superscript ùëâ ùúà V^{2}\equiv g_{\mu\nu}V^{\mu}V^{\nu} italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â° italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the squared norm of V Œº superscript ùëâ ùúá V^{\mu} italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . The metric g Œº ŒΩ subscript ùëî ùúá ùúà g_{\mu\nu} italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the vector field A Œº subscript ùê¥ ùúá A_{\mu} italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are external sources, which respectively source the energy-momentum tensor and the conserved U ( 1 ) ùëà 1 U(1) italic_U ( 1 ) current for the system. The normalization of the temperature is set by T 0 subscript ùëá 0 T_{0} italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , and Œõ V subscript Œõ ùëâ \Lambda_{V} roman_Œõ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ensures that the chemical potential is gauge invariant Jensen:2013kka . The fluid velocity is normalized such that u Œº u Œº = ‚àí 1 subscript ùë¢ ùúá superscript ùë¢ ùúá 1 u_{\mu}u^{\mu}=-1 italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = - 1 . The choice eq.¬†( 1 ) for defining the hydrodynamic variables is called the thermodynamic frame .

We will be interested in a charged fluid with a global U ( 1 ) ùëà 1 U(1) italic_U ( 1 ) symmetry kept in the presence of a strong background magnetic field. By the background magnetic field being strong, we imply that various susceptibilities and transport parameters of the fluid will depend not just upon the temperature and the chemical potential, but also on the strength of the magnetic field, as discussed further below. Given the fluid four-velocity u Œº superscript ùë¢ ùúá u^{\mu} italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , one can express the antisymmetric field strength tensor F Œº ŒΩ subscript ùêπ ùúá ùúà F_{\mu\nu} italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as

F Œº ŒΩ = u Œº E ŒΩ ‚àí u ŒΩ E Œº ‚àí œµ Œº ŒΩ œÅ œÉ u œÅ B œÉ , subscript ùêπ ùúá ùúà subscript ùë¢ ùúá subscript ùê∏ ùúà subscript ùë¢ ùúà subscript ùê∏ ùúá subscript italic-œµ ùúá ùúà ùúå ùúé superscript ùë¢ ùúå superscript ùêµ ùúé F_{\mu\nu}=u_{\mu}E_{\nu}-u_{\nu}E_{\mu}-\epsilon_{\mu\nu\rho\sigma}u^{\rho}B^{\sigma}, italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ italic_œÅ italic_œÉ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œÅ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œÉ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (2)

where the electric and magnetic fields are defined via E Œº ‚â° F Œº ŒΩ u ŒΩ subscript ùê∏ ùúá subscript ùêπ ùúá ùúà superscript ùë¢ ùúà E_{\mu}\equiv F_{\mu\nu}u^{\nu} italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â° italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , B Œº = 1 2 œµ Œº ŒΩ œÅ œÉ u ŒΩ F œÅ œÉ superscript ùêµ ùúá 1 2 superscript italic-œµ ùúá ùúà ùúå ùúé subscript ùë¢ ùúà subscript ùêπ ùúå ùúé B^{\mu}=\frac{1}{2}\epsilon^{\mu\nu\rho\sigma}u_{\nu}F_{\rho\sigma} italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ italic_œÅ italic_œÉ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ italic_œÉ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . Note that both the electric and magnetic fields are orthogonal to the fluid velocity, u ‚ãÖ E = u ‚ãÖ B = 0 ‚ãÖ ùë¢ ùê∏ ‚ãÖ ùë¢ ùêµ 0 u\cdot E=u\cdot B=0 italic_u ‚ãÖ italic_E = italic_u ‚ãÖ italic_B = 0 . Electric and magnetic fields are not independent, but linked to each other via the Bianchi identity œµ Œº ŒΩ œÅ œÉ ‚àá ŒΩ F œÅ œÉ = 0 superscript italic-œµ ùúá ùúà ùúå ùúé subscript ‚àá ùúà subscript ùêπ ùúå ùúé 0 \epsilon^{\mu\nu\rho\sigma}\nabla_{\nu}F_{\rho\sigma}=0 italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ italic_œÅ italic_œÉ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ italic_œÉ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 , which in thermal equilibrium becomes Hernandez:2017mch

‚àá ‚ãÖ B = B ‚ãÖ a ‚àí E ‚ãÖ Œ© , ‚ãÖ ‚àá ùêµ ‚ãÖ ùêµ ùëé ‚ãÖ ùê∏ Œ© \displaystyle\nabla\cdot B=B\cdot a-E\cdot\Omega, ‚àá ‚ãÖ italic_B = italic_B ‚ãÖ italic_a - italic_E ‚ãÖ roman_Œ© , (3a)
u Œº œµ Œº ŒΩ œÅ œÉ ‚àá œÅ E œÉ = u Œº œµ Œº ŒΩ œÅ œÉ E œÅ a œÉ , subscript ùë¢ ùúá superscript italic-œµ ùúá ùúà ùúå ùúé subscript ‚àá ùúå subscript ùê∏ ùúé subscript ùë¢ ùúá superscript italic-œµ ùúá ùúà ùúå ùúé subscript ùê∏ ùúå subscript ùëé ùúé \displaystyle u_{\mu}\epsilon^{\mu\nu\rho\sigma}\nabla_{\rho}E_{\sigma}=u_{\mu}\epsilon^{\mu\nu\rho\sigma}E_{\rho}a_{\sigma}, italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ italic_œÅ italic_œÉ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÉ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ italic_œÅ italic_œÉ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÉ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (3b)

where a Œº = u ŒΩ ‚àá ŒΩ u Œº superscript ùëé ùúá superscript ùë¢ ùúà subscript ‚àá ùúà superscript ùë¢ ùúá a^{\mu}=u^{\nu}\nabla_{\nu}u^{\mu} italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the acceleration and Œ© Œº = œµ Œº ŒΩ œÅ œÉ u ŒΩ ‚àá œÅ u œÉ superscript Œ© ùúá superscript italic-œµ ùúá ùúà ùúå ùúé subscript ùë¢ ùúà subscript ‚àá ùúå subscript ùë¢ ùúé \Omega^{\mu}=\epsilon^{\mu\nu\rho\sigma}u_{\nu}\nabla_{\rho}u_{\sigma} roman_Œ© start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ italic_œÅ italic_œÉ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÉ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the vorticity of the fluid. Note that eqs.¬†( 2 ) are the curved space analogues of the flat space equilibrium identities ‚àá ‚ãÖ ùêÅ = 0 , ‚àá √ó ùêÑ = 0 formulae-sequence ‚ãÖ ‚àá ùêÅ 0 ‚àá ùêÑ 0 {{\bf\nabla\cdot B}=0,{\bf\nabla\times E}=0} ‚àá ‚ãÖ bold_B = 0 , ‚àá √ó bold_E = 0 .

In thermal equilibrium, the correlation functions of conserved currents can be obtained from an equilibrium generating functional ùí≤ [ g Œº ŒΩ , A Œº ] ùí≤ subscript ùëî ùúá ùúà subscript ùê¥ ùúá \mathcal{W}[g_{\mu\nu},A_{\mu}] caligraphic_W [ italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] , which is a functional of the external sources Banerjee:2012iz ; Jensen:2012jh . 1 1 1 As an aside, the equilibrium generating functional can be promoted to be the equilibrium effective action, and can be used to derive effective Einstein‚Äôs equations incorporating the effects of derivative corrections beyond the perfect fluid approximation Kovtun:2019wjz . See Kovtun:2016lfw for a similar analysis for electromagnetism. The variation of ùí≤ ùí≤ \mathcal{W} caligraphic_W with respect to the sources gives

Œ¥ ùí≤ = 1 2 ‚à´ d 4 x ‚àí g T Œº ŒΩ Œ¥ g Œº ŒΩ + ‚à´ d 4 x ‚àí g J Œº Œ¥ A Œº , ùõø ùí≤ 1 2 superscript ùëë 4 ùë• ùëî superscript ùëá ùúá ùúà ùõø subscript ùëî ùúá ùúà superscript ùëë 4 ùë• ùëî superscript ùêΩ ùúá ùõø subscript ùê¥ ùúá \delta\mathcal{W}=\frac{1}{2}\int d^{4}x\sqrt{-g}\,T^{\mu\nu}\delta g_{\mu\nu}+\int d^{4}x\sqrt{-g}\,J^{\mu}\delta A_{\mu}, italic_Œ¥ caligraphic_W = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚à´ italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x square-root start_ARG - italic_g end_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ¥ italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ‚à´ italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x square-root start_ARG - italic_g end_ARG italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ¥ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (4)

which implies that the one-point functions of the conserved currents are

T Œº ŒΩ = 2 ‚àí g Œ¥ ùí≤ Œ¥ g Œº ŒΩ , J Œº = 1 ‚àí g Œ¥ ùí≤ Œ¥ A Œº . formulae-sequence superscript ùëá ùúá ùúà 2 ùëî ùõø ùí≤ ùõø subscript ùëî ùúá ùúà superscript ùêΩ ùúá 1 ùëî ùõø ùí≤ ùõø subscript ùê¥ ùúá T^{\mu\nu}=\frac{2}{\sqrt{-g}}\frac{\delta\mathcal{W}}{\delta g_{\mu\nu}}\,,\quad J^{\mu}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{-g}}\frac{\delta\mathcal{W}}{\delta A_{\mu}}. italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG - italic_g end_ARG end_ARG divide start_ARG italic_Œ¥ caligraphic_W end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œ¥ italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG - italic_g end_ARG end_ARG divide start_ARG italic_Œ¥ caligraphic_W end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œ¥ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG . (5)

Higher point correlation functions in equilibrium can be obtained by taking further derivatives with respect to the sources. The conservation equations

‚àá Œº T Œº ŒΩ = F ŒΩ œÅ J œÅ , subscript ‚àá ùúá superscript ùëá ùúá ùúà superscript ùêπ ùúà ùúå subscript ùêΩ ùúå \displaystyle\nabla_{\mu}T^{\mu\nu}=F^{\nu\rho}J_{\rho}, ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ italic_œÅ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (6a)
‚àá Œº J Œº = 0 , subscript ‚àá ùúá superscript ùêΩ ùúá 0 \displaystyle\nabla_{\mu}J^{\mu}=0, ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0 , (6b)

follow from the diffeomorphism and gauge invariance of the generating functional. The generating functional can be expressed as an integral over a local free energy density ‚Ñ± ‚Ñ± \mathcal{F} caligraphic_F via

ùí≤ [ g Œº ŒΩ , A Œº ] = ‚à´ d 4 x ‚àí g ‚Ñ± ( g Œº ŒΩ , A Œº ) . ùí≤ subscript ùëî ùúá ùúà subscript ùê¥ ùúá superscript ùëë 4 ùë• ùëî ‚Ñ± subscript ùëî ùúá ùúà subscript ùê¥ ùúá \mathcal{W}[g_{\mu\nu},A_{\mu}]=\int d^{4}x\sqrt{-g}\,\mathcal{F}(g_{\mu\nu},A_{\mu}). caligraphic_W [ italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = ‚à´ italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x square-root start_ARG - italic_g end_ARG caligraphic_F ( italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (7)

When the sources vary on length scales much longer than the inherent microscopic scales in the system, such as the correlation length, the density ‚Ñ± ‚Ñ± \mathcal{F} caligraphic_F admits an expansion in terms of the derivatives of the hydrodynamic variables and the sources Banerjee:2012iz ; Jensen:2012jh . At zeroth order in the derivative expansion, for instance, we have

‚Ñ± ( 0 ) = p ( T , Œº , B 2 ) , superscript ‚Ñ± 0 ùëù ùëá ùúá superscript ùêµ 2 \mathcal{F}^{(0)}=p(T,\mu,B^{2}), caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_p ( italic_T , italic_Œº , italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (8)

where p ùëù p italic_p is the equilibrium pressure.

An important point here is the choice of the derivative counting scheme. The metric is naturally counted as ùí™ ( 1 ) ùí™ 1 \mathcal{O}(1) caligraphic_O ( 1 ) . For conducting fluids in the presence of strong magnetic fields, the appropriate derivative counting scheme is B Œº ‚àº ùí™ ( 1 ) similar-to superscript ùêµ ùúá ùí™ 1 B^{\mu}\sim\mathcal{O}(1) italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àº caligraphic_O ( 1 ) . Electric field in equilibrium satisfies the condition ‚àÇ Œª Œº = E Œª ‚àí Œº a Œª subscript ùúÜ ùúá subscript ùê∏ ùúÜ ùúá subscript ùëé ùúÜ \partial_{\lambda}\mu=E_{\lambda}-\mu a_{\lambda} ‚àÇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº = italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Œº italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , and hence it is appropriate to consider E Œº ‚àº ùí™ ( ‚àÇ ) similar-to superscript ùê∏ ùúá ùí™ E^{\mu}\sim\mathcal{O}(\partial) italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àº caligraphic_O ( ‚àÇ ) , which is another way to say that the electric field is screened in charged fluids. Since the magnetic field is ùí™ ( 1 ) ùí™ 1 \mathcal{O}(1) caligraphic_O ( 1 ) , the thermodynamic susceptibilities and transport parameters of the fluid will depend upon its strength as well. For instance, the equation of state in eq.¬†( 8 ) has an explicit dependence on B 2 superscript ùêµ 2 B^{2} italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

2.1 The equilibrium constitutive relations

The energy-momentum tensor for the fluid can be decomposed into components along and orthogonal to the fluid four-velocity u Œº superscript ùë¢ ùúá u^{\mu} italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT via

T Œº ŒΩ = ‚Ñ∞ u Œº u ŒΩ + ùí´ Œî Œº ŒΩ + ùí¨ Œº u ŒΩ + ùí¨ ŒΩ u Œº + ùíØ Œº ŒΩ , superscript ùëá ùúá ùúà ‚Ñ∞ superscript ùë¢ ùúá superscript ùë¢ ùúà ùí´ superscript Œî ùúá ùúà superscript ùí¨ ùúá superscript ùë¢ ùúà superscript ùí¨ ùúà superscript ùë¢ ùúá superscript ùíØ ùúá ùúà T^{\mu\nu}=\mathcal{E}u^{\mu}u^{\nu}+\mathcal{P}\Delta^{\mu\nu}+\mathcal{Q}^{\mu}u^{\nu}+\mathcal{Q}^{\nu}u^{\mu}+\mathcal{T}^{\mu\nu}, italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = caligraphic_E italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + caligraphic_P roman_Œî start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (9)

where Œî Œº ŒΩ = g Œº ŒΩ + u Œº u ŒΩ subscript Œî ùúá ùúà subscript ùëî ùúá ùúà subscript ùë¢ ùúá subscript ùë¢ ùúà \Delta_{\mu\nu}=g_{\mu\nu}+u_{\mu}u_{\nu} roman_Œî start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the projector orthogonal to the fluid velocity, the heat current ùí¨ Œº superscript ùí¨ ùúá \mathcal{Q}^{\mu} caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is orthogonal to the fluid velocity, and ùíØ Œº ŒΩ superscript ùíØ ùúá ùúà \mathcal{T}^{\mu\nu} caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is symmetric, traceless and transverse to the fluid velocity. Given T Œº ŒΩ superscript ùëá ùúá ùúà T^{\mu\nu} italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT one can extract the coefficients via

‚Ñ∞ = u Œº u ŒΩ T Œº ŒΩ , ùí´ = 1 3 Œî Œº ŒΩ T Œº ŒΩ , ùí¨ Œº = ‚àí Œî Œº ŒΩ u œÅ T ŒΩ œÅ ùíØ Œº ŒΩ = 1 2 ( Œî Œº Œ± Œî ŒΩ Œ≤ + Œî Œº Œ≤ Œî ŒΩ Œ± ‚àí 2 3 Œî Œº ŒΩ Œî Œ± Œ≤ ) T Œ± Œ≤ . formulae-sequence ‚Ñ∞ subscript ùë¢ ùúá subscript ùë¢ ùúà superscript ùëá ùúá ùúà formulae-sequence ùí´ 1 3 subscript Œî ùúá ùúà superscript ùëá ùúá ùúà subscript ùí¨ ùúá subscript Œî ùúá ùúà subscript ùë¢ ùúå superscript ùëá ùúà ùúå subscript ùíØ ùúá ùúà 1 2 subscript Œî ùúá ùõº subscript Œî ùúà ùõΩ subscript Œî ùúá ùõΩ subscript Œî ùúà ùõº 2 3 subscript Œî ùúá ùúà subscript Œî ùõº ùõΩ superscript ùëá ùõº ùõΩ \begin{split}&\mathcal{E}=u_{\mu}u_{\nu}T^{\mu\nu},\,\,\mathcal{P}=\frac{1}{3}\Delta_{\mu\nu}T^{\mu\nu},\,\,\mathcal{Q}_{\mu}=-\Delta_{\mu\nu}u_{\rho}T^{\nu\rho}\\ &\mathcal{T}_{\mu\nu}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\Delta_{\mu\alpha}\Delta_{\nu\beta}+\Delta_{\mu\beta}\Delta_{\nu\alpha}-\frac{2}{3}\Delta_{\mu\nu}\Delta_{\alpha\beta}\right)T^{\alpha\beta}.\end{split} start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL caligraphic_E = italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_P = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG roman_Œî start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - roman_Œî start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ italic_œÅ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( roman_Œî start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_Œ± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œî start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_Œî start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œî start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ italic_Œ± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG roman_Œî start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œî start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ± italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . end_CELL end_ROW (10)

In the hydrodynamic regime, the quantities ‚Ñ∞ , ùí´ , ùí¨ Œº , ùíØ Œº ŒΩ ‚Ñ∞ ùí´ superscript ùí¨ ùúá superscript ùíØ ùúá ùúà \mathcal{E},\mathcal{P},\mathcal{Q}^{\mu},\mathcal{T}^{\mu\nu} caligraphic_E , caligraphic_P , caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can be expanded in a series in the number of derivatives acting on the hydrodynamic variables and the sources, which are called the constitutive relations for the fluid. Just like the energy-momentum tensor, the conserved U ( 1 ) ùëà 1 U(1) italic_U ( 1 ) current can also be decomposed as

J Œº = ùí© u Œº + ùí• Œº , superscript ùêΩ ùúá ùí© superscript ùë¢ ùúá superscript ùí• ùúá J^{\mu}=\mathcal{N}u^{\mu}+\mathcal{J}^{\mu}, italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = caligraphic_N italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + caligraphic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (11)

where ùí• Œº superscript ùí• ùúá \mathcal{J}^{\mu} caligraphic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is transverse to the fluid velocity. Given the current J Œº superscript ùêΩ ùúá J^{\mu} italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , one can extract the coefficients in eq. ( 11 ) via

ùí© = ‚àí u Œº J Œº , ùí• Œº = Œî Œº ŒΩ J ŒΩ . formulae-sequence ùí© subscript ùë¢ ùúá superscript ùêΩ ùúá subscript ùí• ùúá subscript Œî ùúá ùúà superscript ùêΩ ùúà \mathcal{N}=-u_{\mu}J^{\mu},\,\,\mathcal{J}_{\mu}=\Delta_{\mu\nu}J^{\nu}. caligraphic_N = - italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_Œî start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (12)

2.1.1 The zeroth order

As an illustration, let us compute the constitutive relations for the fluid at the zeroth order in the derivative expansion Hernandez:2017mch . The equilibrium generating functional at the zeroth order in derivatives is given by

ùí≤ [ g Œº ŒΩ , A Œº ] = ‚à´ d 4 x ‚àí g p ( T , Œº , B 2 ) . ùí≤ subscript ùëî ùúá ùúà subscript ùê¥ ùúá superscript ùëë 4 ùë• ùëî ùëù ùëá ùúá superscript ùêµ 2 \mathcal{W}[g_{\mu\nu},A_{\mu}]=\int d^{4}x\sqrt{-g}\,p(T,\mu,B^{2}). caligraphic_W [ italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = ‚à´ italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x square-root start_ARG - italic_g end_ARG italic_p ( italic_T , italic_Œº , italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (13)

Varying it with respect to the sources g Œº ŒΩ subscript ùëî ùúá ùúà g_{\mu\nu} italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and A Œº subscript ùê¥ ùúá A_{\mu} italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT gives the zeroth order constitutive relations,

‚Ñ∞ = ‚àí p + T ‚àÇ p ‚àÇ T + Œº ‚àÇ p ‚àÇ Œº ‚â° œµ ( T , Œº , B 2 ) , ‚Ñ∞ ùëù ùëá ùëù ùëá ùúá ùëù ùúá italic-œµ ùëá ùúá superscript ùêµ 2 \displaystyle\mathcal{E}=-p+T\frac{\partial p}{\partial T}+\mu\frac{\partial p}{\partial\mu}\equiv\epsilon(T,\mu,B^{2}), caligraphic_E = - italic_p + italic_T divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_p end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_T end_ARG + italic_Œº divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_p end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_Œº end_ARG ‚â° italic_œµ ( italic_T , italic_Œº , italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (14a)
ùí´ = p ‚àí 2 3 Œ± BB B 2 , ùí´ ùëù 2 3 subscript ùõº BB superscript ùêµ 2 \displaystyle\mathcal{P}=p-\frac{2}{3}\alpha_{\rm BB}B^{2}, caligraphic_P = italic_p - divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_BB end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (14b)
ùí© = ‚àÇ p ‚àÇ Œº ‚â° n ( T , Œº , B 2 ) , ùí© ùëù ùúá ùëõ ùëá ùúá superscript ùêµ 2 \displaystyle\mathcal{N}=\frac{\partial p}{\partial\mu}\equiv n(T,\mu,B^{2}), caligraphic_N = divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_p end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_Œº end_ARG ‚â° italic_n ( italic_T , italic_Œº , italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (14c)
ùíØ Œº ŒΩ = Œ± B B ( B Œº B ŒΩ ‚àí 1 3 Œî Œº ŒΩ B 2 ) , superscript ùíØ ùúá ùúà subscript ùõº ùêµ ùêµ superscript ùêµ ùúá superscript ùêµ ùúà 1 3 superscript Œî ùúá ùúà superscript ùêµ 2 \displaystyle\mathcal{T}^{\mu\nu}=\alpha_{BB}\left(B^{\mu}B^{\nu}-\frac{1}{3}\Delta^{\mu\nu}B^{2}\right), caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG roman_Œî start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (14d)

where œµ ( T , Œº , B 2 ) italic-œµ ùëá ùúá superscript ùêµ 2 \epsilon(T,\mu,B^{2}) italic_œµ ( italic_T , italic_Œº , italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is the equilibrium energy density and n ( T , Œº , B 2 ) ùëõ ùëá ùúá superscript ùêµ 2 n(T,\mu,B^{2}) italic_n ( italic_T , italic_Œº , italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is the equilibrium charge density. Also, Œ± BB ( T , Œº , B 2 ) = 2 ‚àÇ p / ‚àÇ B 2 subscript ùõº BB ùëá ùúá superscript ùêµ 2 2 ùëù superscript ùêµ 2 \alpha_{\rm BB}(T,\mu,B^{2})=2\partial p/\partial B^{2} italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_BB end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_T , italic_Œº , italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 2 ‚àÇ italic_p / ‚àÇ italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denotes the magnetic susceptibility. At the zeroth order, one has ùí¨ Œº = ùí• Œº = 0 superscript ùí¨ ùúá superscript ùí• ùúá 0 \mathcal{Q}^{\mu}=\mathcal{J}^{\mu}=0 caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = caligraphic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0 .

2.1.2 The first order

For a parity violating fluid, at the first order in derivatives in thermal equilibrium, there are five independent scalars that can contribute to the generating functional ùí≤ [ g Œº ŒΩ , A Œº ] ùí≤ subscript ùëî ùúá ùúà subscript ùê¥ ùúá \mathcal{W}[g_{\mu\nu},A_{\mu}] caligraphic_W [ italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] , which consequently takes the form Hernandez:2017mch 2 2 2 Note that when the magnetic field is weak, B Œº ‚àº ùí™ ( ‚àÇ ) similar-to superscript ùêµ ùúá ùí™ B^{\mu}\sim\mathcal{O}(\partial) italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àº caligraphic_O ( ‚àÇ ) , derivative contributions to the equilibrium generating functional begin at the second order Kovtun:2018dvd . See also Shukla:2019shf for the behaviour of second order susceptibilities for free quantum field theories as a function of Œº , T ùúá ùëá \mu,T italic_Œº , italic_T .

ùí≤ = ‚à´ d 4 x ‚àí g ( p ( T , Œº , B 2 ) + ‚àë i = 1 5 M i ( T , Œº , B 2 ) S i ) , ùí≤ superscript ùëë 4 ùë• ùëî ùëù ùëá ùúá superscript ùêµ 2 superscript subscript ùëñ 1 5 subscript ùëÄ ùëñ ùëá ùúá superscript ùêµ 2 subscript ùëÜ ùëñ \mathcal{W}=\int d^{4}x\sqrt{-g}\left(p(T,\mu,B^{2})+\sum_{i=1}^{5}M_{i}(T,\mu,B^{2})\,S_{i}\right), caligraphic_W = ‚à´ italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x square-root start_ARG - italic_g end_ARG ( italic_p ( italic_T , italic_Œº , italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_T , italic_Œº , italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (15)

where the one-derivative scalars S i subscript ùëÜ ùëñ S_{i} italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are

S 1 = B Œº ‚àÇ Œº ( B 2 T 4 ) , S 2 = œµ Œº ŒΩ œÅ œÉ u Œº B ŒΩ ‚àá œÅ B œÉ , S 3 = B ‚ãÖ a , S 4 = B ‚ãÖ Œ© , S 5 = B ‚ãÖ E . formulae-sequence subscript ùëÜ 1 superscript ùêµ ùúá subscript ùúá superscript ùêµ 2 superscript ùëá 4 formulae-sequence subscript ùëÜ 2 superscript italic-œµ ùúá ùúà ùúå ùúé subscript ùë¢ ùúá subscript ùêµ ùúà subscript ‚àá ùúå subscript ùêµ ùúé formulae-sequence subscript ùëÜ 3 ‚ãÖ ùêµ ùëé formulae-sequence subscript ùëÜ 4 ‚ãÖ ùêµ Œ© subscript ùëÜ 5 ‚ãÖ ùêµ ùê∏ \begin{split}&S_{1}=B^{\mu}\partial_{\mu}\left(\frac{B^{2}}{T^{4}}\right),\,\,S_{2}=\epsilon^{\mu\nu\rho\sigma}u_{\mu}B_{\nu}\nabla_{\rho}B_{\sigma},\\ &S_{3}=B\cdot a,\,\,S_{4}=B\cdot\Omega,\,\,S_{5}=B\cdot E.\end{split} start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àÇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ italic_œÅ italic_œÉ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÉ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_B ‚ãÖ italic_a , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_B ‚ãÖ roman_Œ© , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_B ‚ãÖ italic_E . end_CELL end_ROW (16)

Out of these, only S 4 subscript ùëÜ 4 S_{4} italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is parity preserving, and the rest are parity violating. Also, M i ( T , Œº , B 2 ) subscript ùëÄ ùëñ ùëá ùúá superscript ùêµ 2 M_{i}(T,\mu,B^{2}) italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_T , italic_Œº , italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) are thermodynamic susceptibilities and need to be determined from the microscopic theory, just like the pressure p ùëù p italic_p .

Our focus in the present work is on parity preserving fluids in 3+1D. 3 3 3 See Abbasi:2015saa ; Abbasi:2016rds ; Ammon:2020rvg for computations in 3+1D where parity violation is considered. Additionally, see Hartnoll:2007ih ; Baggioli:2020edn ; Amoretti:2020mkp ; Amoretti:2021fch for the effects of strong background magnetic fields in 2+1D. Thus, for our purposes, the equilibrium generating functional up to first order in derivatives is given by (with the susceptibility M 4 subscript ùëÄ 4 M_{4} italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denoted more suggestively by M Œ© subscript ùëÄ Œ© M_{\Omega} italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )

ùí≤ = ‚à´ d 4 x ‚àí g [ p ( T , Œº , B 2 ) + M Œ© B ‚ãÖ Œ© ] . ùí≤ superscript ùëë 4 ùë• ùëî delimited-[] ùëù ùëá ùúá superscript ùêµ 2 ‚ãÖ subscript ùëÄ Œ© ùêµ Œ© \mathcal{W}=\int d^{4}x\sqrt{-g}\,\left[p(T,\mu,B^{2})+M_{\Omega}\,B\cdot\Omega\right]. caligraphic_W = ‚à´ italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x square-root start_ARG - italic_g end_ARG [ italic_p ( italic_T , italic_Œº , italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B ‚ãÖ roman_Œ© ] . (17)

Varying this with respect to the metric g Œº ŒΩ subscript ùëî ùúá ùúà g_{\mu\nu} italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT gives us the following first order constitutive relations for the energy-momentum tensor eq.¬†( 9 ), 4 4 4 The terms in the last line of eq.¬†( 18d ) have extra factors of 2 when compared with the results in Hernandez:2017mch . This is so because the authors of Hernandez:2017mch use two different definitions for the projection A ‚ü® Œº B ŒΩ ‚ü© A^{\langle\mu}B^{\nu\rangle} italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ü® italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ ‚ü© end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , whereas we uniformly use the definition given in eq.¬†( 20 ).

‚Ñ∞ = œµ + ( T M Œ© , T + Œº M Œ© , Œº ‚àí 2 M Œ© ) B ‚ãÖ Œ© , ‚Ñ∞ italic-œµ ‚ãÖ ùëá subscript ùëÄ Œ© ùëá ùúá subscript ùëÄ Œ© ùúá 2 subscript ùëÄ Œ© ùêµ Œ© \displaystyle\mathcal{E}=\epsilon+\left(TM_{\Omega,T}+\mu M_{\Omega,\mu}-2M_{\Omega}\right)B\cdot\Omega\,, caligraphic_E = italic_œµ + ( italic_T italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ© , italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œº italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ© , italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 2 italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_B ‚ãÖ roman_Œ© , (18a)
ùí´ = p ‚àí 2 3 Œ± BB B 2 ‚àí 1 3 ( M Œ© + 4 B 2 M Œ© , B 2 ) B ‚ãÖ Œ© , ùí´ ùëù 2 3 subscript ùõº BB superscript ùêµ 2 ‚ãÖ 1 3 subscript ùëÄ Œ© 4 superscript ùêµ 2 subscript ùëÄ Œ© superscript ùêµ 2 ùêµ Œ© \displaystyle\mathcal{P}=p-\frac{2}{3}\alpha_{\rm BB}B^{2}-\frac{1}{3}\left(M_{\Omega}+4B^{2}M_{\Omega,B^{2}}\right)B\cdot\Omega\,, caligraphic_P = italic_p - divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_BB end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ( italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 4 italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ© , italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_B ‚ãÖ roman_Œ© , (18b)
ùí¨ Œº = M Œ© œµ Œº ŒΩ œÅ œÉ u ŒΩ ‚àÇ œÅ B œÉ ‚àí M Œ© , B 2 œµ Œº ŒΩ œÅ œÉ u ŒΩ B œÅ ‚àÇ œÉ B 2 + ( 2 M Œ© ‚àí T M Œ© , T ‚àí Œº M Œ© , Œº ) œµ Œº ŒΩ œÅ œÉ B ŒΩ u œÅ a œÉ superscript ùí¨ ùúá subscript ùëÄ Œ© superscript italic-œµ ùúá ùúà ùúå ùúé subscript ùë¢ ùúà subscript ùúå subscript ùêµ ùúé subscript ùëÄ Œ© superscript ùêµ 2 superscript italic-œµ ùúá ùúà ùúå ùúé subscript ùë¢ ùúà subscript ùêµ ùúå subscript ùúé superscript ùêµ 2 2 subscript ùëÄ Œ© ùëá subscript ùëÄ Œ© ùëá ùúá subscript ùëÄ Œ© ùúá superscript italic-œµ ùúá ùúà ùúå ùúé subscript ùêµ ùúà subscript ùë¢ ùúå subscript ùëé ùúé \displaystyle\mathcal{Q}^{\mu}=M_{\Omega}\epsilon^{\mu\nu\rho\sigma}u_{\nu}\partial_{\rho}B_{\sigma}-M_{\Omega,B^{2}}\epsilon^{\mu\nu\rho\sigma}u_{\nu}B_{\rho}\partial_{\sigma}B^{2}+\left(2M_{\Omega}-TM_{\Omega,T}-\mu M_{\Omega,\mu}\right)\epsilon^{\mu\nu\rho\sigma}B_{\nu}u_{\rho}a_{\sigma} caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ italic_œÅ italic_œÉ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àÇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÉ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - + ( M Œ© , Œº ‚àí 2 M Œ© , B 2 B ‚ãÖ Œ© ‚àí Œ± B B ) œµ Œº ŒΩ œÅ œÉ u ŒΩ E œÅ B œÉ + M Œ© œµ Œº ŒΩ œÅ œÉ Œ© ŒΩ E œÅ u œÉ , subscript ùëÄ Œ© ùúá ‚ãÖ 2 subscript ùëÄ Œ© superscript ùêµ 2 ùêµ Œ© subscript ùõº ùêµ ùêµ superscript italic-œµ ùúá ùúà ùúå ùúé subscript ùë¢ ùúà subscript ùê∏ ùúå subscript ùêµ ùúé subscript ùëÄ Œ© superscript italic-œµ ùúá ùúà ùúå ùúé subscript Œ© ùúà subscript ùê∏ ùúå subscript ùë¢ ùúé \displaystyle\quad\quad+\left(M_{\Omega,\mu}-2M_{\Omega,B^{2}}B\cdot\Omega-\alpha_{BB}\right)\epsilon^{\mu\nu\rho\sigma}u_{\nu}E_{\rho}B_{\sigma}+M_{\Omega}\epsilon^{\mu\nu\rho\sigma}\Omega_{\nu}E_{\rho}u_{\sigma}\,, + ( italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ© , italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 2 italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ© , italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B ‚ãÖ roman_Œ© - italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ italic_œÅ italic_œÉ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÉ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ italic_œÅ italic_œÉ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Œ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÉ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (18c)
ùíØ Œº ŒΩ = Œ± BB ( B Œº B ŒΩ ‚àí 1 3 Œî Œº ŒΩ B 2 ) + 2 M Œ© , B 2 B ‚ãÖ Œ© B ‚ü® Œº B ŒΩ ‚ü© + 2 M Œ© B ‚ü® Œº Œ© ŒΩ ‚ü© , \displaystyle\mathcal{T}^{\mu\nu}=\alpha_{\rm BB}\left(B^{\mu}B^{\nu}-\frac{1}{3}\Delta^{\mu\nu}B^{2}\right)+2M_{\Omega,B^{2}}B\cdot\Omega\,B^{\langle\mu}B^{\nu\rangle}+2M_{\Omega}B^{\langle\mu}\Omega^{\nu\rangle}\,, caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_BB end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG roman_Œî start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + 2 italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ© , italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B ‚ãÖ roman_Œ© italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ü® italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ ‚ü© end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ü® italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Œ© start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ ‚ü© end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (18d)

with Œ± BB = 2 ‚àÇ p / ‚àÇ B 2 subscript ùõº BB 2 ùëù superscript ùêµ 2 \alpha_{\rm BB}=2\partial p/\partial B^{2} italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_BB end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 2 ‚àÇ italic_p / ‚àÇ italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as defined earlier. A comma in the subscript denotes a partial derivative with respect to the argument that follows. In deriving the constitutive relations in eqs.¬†( 2.1.1 ) and ( 2.1.2 ), we made use of the following intermediate results for the variation of various quantities that enter the generating functional under a variation of the metric. These are

Œ¥ T = T 2 u Œº u ŒΩ Œ¥ g Œº ŒΩ , ùõø ùëá ùëá 2 superscript ùë¢ ùúá superscript ùë¢ ùúà ùõø subscript ùëî ùúá ùúà \displaystyle\delta T=\frac{T}{2}\,u^{\mu}u^{\nu}\delta g_{\mu\nu}\,, italic_Œ¥ italic_T = divide start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ¥ italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (19a)

Œ¥ B Œº = ‚àí 1 2 B Œº Œî Œ± Œ≤ Œ¥ g Œ± Œ≤ + u Œº u Œ± B Œ≤ Œ¥ g Œ± Œ≤ + œµ Œº Œ± œÅ œÉ u Œ≤ u œÅ E œÉ Œ¥ g Œ± Œ≤ , ùõø superscript ùêµ ùúá 1 2 superscript ùêµ ùúá superscript Œî ùõº ùõΩ ùõø subscript ùëî ùõº ùõΩ superscript ùë¢ ùúá superscript ùë¢ ùõº superscript ùêµ ùõΩ ùõø subscript ùëî ùõº ùõΩ superscript italic-œµ ùúá ùõº ùúå ùúé superscript ùë¢ ùõΩ subscript ùë¢ ùúå subscript ùê∏ ùúé ùõø subscript ùëî ùõº ùõΩ \displaystyle\delta B^{\mu}=-\frac{1}{2}B^{\mu}\Delta^{\alpha\beta}\delta g_{\alpha\beta}+u^{\mu}u^{\alpha}B^{\beta}\delta g_{\alpha\beta}+\epsilon^{\mu\alpha\rho\sigma}u^{\beta}u_{\rho}E_{\sigma}\delta g_{\alpha\beta}\,, italic_Œ¥ italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Œî start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ± italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ¥ italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ¥ italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_Œ± italic_œÅ italic_œÉ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÉ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ¥ italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (19c)
Œ¥ B 2 = B Œº B ŒΩ Œ¥ g Œº ŒΩ ‚àí B 2 Œî Œº ŒΩ Œ¥ g Œº ŒΩ ‚àí 2 œµ Œº ŒΩ œÅ œÉ u ŒΩ E œÅ B œÉ u Œ± Œ¥ g Œº Œ± , ùõø superscript ùêµ 2 superscript ùêµ ùúá superscript ùêµ ùúà ùõø subscript ùëî ùúá ùúà superscript ùêµ 2 superscript Œî ùúá ùúà ùõø subscript ùëî ùúá ùúà 2 superscript italic-œµ ùúá ùúà ùúå ùúé subscript ùë¢ ùúà subscript ùê∏ ùúå subscript ùêµ ùúé superscript ùë¢ ùõº ùõø subscript ùëî ùúá ùõº \displaystyle\delta B^{2}=B^{\mu}B^{\nu}\delta g_{\mu\nu}-B^{2}\Delta^{\mu\nu}\delta g_{\mu\nu}-2\epsilon^{\mu\nu\rho\sigma}u_{\nu}E_{\rho}B_{\sigma}u^{\alpha}\delta g_{\mu\alpha}\,, italic_Œ¥ italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ¥ italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Œî start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ¥ italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 2 italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ italic_œÅ italic_œÉ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÉ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ¥ italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_Œ± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (19d)
Œ¥ Œ© Œº = Œ© Œº ( u Œ± u Œ≤ ‚àí 1 2 g Œ± Œ≤ ) Œ¥ g Œ± Œ≤ + œµ Œº ŒΩ œÅ œÉ u Œ± ‚àá œÅ u œÉ Œ¥ g ŒΩ Œ± + œµ Œº ŒΩ œÅ œÉ u ŒΩ ‚àÇ œÅ u Œ± Œ¥ g Œ± œÉ + œµ Œº ŒΩ œÅ œÉ u ŒΩ u Œ± ‚àÇ œÅ Œ¥ g Œ± œÉ ùõø superscript Œ© ùúá superscript Œ© ùúá superscript ùë¢ ùõº superscript ùë¢ ùõΩ 1 2 superscript ùëî ùõº ùõΩ ùõø subscript ùëî ùõº ùõΩ superscript italic-œµ ùúá ùúà ùúå ùúé superscript ùë¢ ùõº subscript ‚àá ùúå subscript ùë¢ ùúé ùõø subscript ùëî ùúà ùõº superscript italic-œµ ùúá ùúà ùúå ùúé subscript ùë¢ ùúà subscript ùúå superscript ùë¢ ùõº ùõø subscript ùëî ùõº ùúé superscript italic-œµ ùúá ùúà ùúå ùúé subscript ùë¢ ùúà superscript ùë¢ ùõº subscript ùúå ùõø subscript ùëî ùõº ùúé \displaystyle\delta\Omega^{\mu}=\Omega^{\mu}\left(u^{\alpha}u^{\beta}-\frac{1}{2}g^{\alpha\beta}\right)\delta g_{\alpha\beta}+\epsilon^{\mu\nu\rho\sigma}u^{\alpha}\nabla_{\rho}u_{\sigma}\delta g_{\nu\alpha}+\epsilon^{\mu\nu\rho\sigma}u_{\nu}\partial_{\rho}u^{\alpha}\delta g_{\alpha\sigma}+\epsilon^{\mu\nu\rho\sigma}u_{\nu}u^{\alpha}\partial_{\rho}\delta g_{\alpha\sigma} italic_Œ¥ roman_Œ© start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_Œ© start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - Œ¥ ( B ‚ãÖ Œ© ) = B Œº Œ© ŒΩ Œ¥ g Œº ŒΩ + ( 1 2 u Œº u ŒΩ ‚àí g Œº ŒΩ ) B ‚ãÖ Œ© Œ¥ g Œº ŒΩ ùõø ‚ãÖ ùêµ Œ© superscript ùêµ ùúá superscript Œ© ùúà ùõø subscript ùëî ùúá ùúà ‚ãÖ 1 2 superscript ùë¢ ùúá superscript ùë¢ ùúà superscript ùëî ùúá ùúà ùêµ Œ© ùõø subscript ùëî ùúá ùúà \displaystyle\delta(B\cdot\Omega)=B^{\mu}\Omega^{\nu}\delta g_{\mu\nu}+\left(\frac{1}{2}u^{\mu}u^{\nu}-g^{\mu\nu}\right)B\cdot\Omega\,\delta g_{\mu\nu} italic_Œ¥ ( italic_B ‚ãÖ roman_Œ© ) = italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Œ© start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ¥ italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_B ‚ãÖ roman_Œ© italic_Œ¥ italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
‚àí œµ Œº Œ± Œ≤ œÅ B Œ± ‚àá Œ≤ u œÅ u ŒΩ Œ¥ g Œº ŒΩ ‚àí œµ Œº Œ± Œ≤ œÅ B Œ± u Œ≤ ‚àÇ œÅ u ŒΩ Œ¥ g Œº ŒΩ ‚àí œµ Œº Œ± Œ≤ œÅ B Œ± u Œ≤ u ŒΩ ‚àÇ œÅ Œ¥ g Œº ŒΩ . superscript italic-œµ ùúá ùõº ùõΩ ùúå subscript ùêµ ùõº subscript ‚àá ùõΩ subscript ùë¢ ùúå superscript ùë¢ ùúà ùõø subscript ùëî ùúá ùúà superscript italic-œµ ùúá ùõº ùõΩ ùúå subscript ùêµ ùõº subscript ùë¢ ùõΩ subscript ùúå superscript ùë¢ ùúà ùõø subscript ùëî ùúá ùúà superscript italic-œµ ùúá ùõº ùõΩ ùúå subscript ùêµ ùõº subscript ùë¢ ùõΩ superscript ùë¢ ùúà subscript ùúå ùõø subscript ùëî ùúá ùúà \displaystyle\qquad\qquad-\epsilon^{\mu\alpha\beta\rho}B_{\alpha}\nabla_{\beta}u_{\rho}\,u^{\nu}\delta g_{\mu\nu}-\epsilon^{\mu\alpha\beta\rho}B_{\alpha}u_{\beta}\partial_{\rho}u^{\nu}\delta g_{\mu\nu}-\epsilon^{\mu\alpha\beta\rho}B_{\alpha}u_{\beta}u^{\nu}\partial_{\rho}\delta g_{\mu\nu}. - italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_Œ± italic_Œ≤ italic_œÅ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ¥ italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_Œ± italic_Œ≤ italic_œÅ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àÇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ¥ italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_Œ± italic_Œ≤ italic_œÅ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àÇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ¥ italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (19f)

Also, the angular bracket notation used above helps in defining the symmetric transverse traceless part of a tensor, given by

A ‚ü® Œº B ŒΩ ‚ü© ‚â° 1 2 ( Œî Œº Œ± Œî ŒΩ Œ≤ + Œî Œº Œ≤ Œî ŒΩ Œ± ‚àí 2 3 Œî Œº ŒΩ Œî Œ± Œ≤ ) A Œ± B Œ≤ . A^{\langle\mu}B^{\nu\rangle}\equiv\frac{1}{2}\left(\Delta^{\mu\alpha}\Delta^{\nu\beta}+\Delta^{\mu\beta}\Delta^{\nu\alpha}-\frac{2}{3}\Delta^{\mu\nu}\Delta^{\alpha\beta}\right)A_{\alpha}B_{\beta}. italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ü® italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ ‚ü© end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â° divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( roman_Œî start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_Œ± end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Œî start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Œî start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Œî start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ italic_Œ± end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG roman_Œî start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Œî start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ± italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (20)

For computing the constitutive relations for the U ( 1 ) ùëà 1 U(1) italic_U ( 1 ) current, it is convenient to regard the generating functional as a functional of A Œº subscript ùê¥ ùúá A_{\mu} italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and its derivative F Œº ŒΩ subscript ùêπ ùúá ùúà F_{\mu\nu} italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . The variation of the generating functional is then defined as Kovtun:2016lfw ; Kovtun:2018dvd

Œ¥ A , F ùí≤ = ‚à´ d 4 x ‚àí g ( J f Œº Œ¥ A Œº + 1 2 M Œº ŒΩ Œ¥ F Œº ŒΩ ) , subscript ùõø ùê¥ ùêπ ùí≤ superscript ùëë 4 ùë• ùëî subscript superscript ùêΩ ùúá ùëì ùõø subscript ùê¥ ùúá 1 2 superscript ùëÄ ùúá ùúà ùõø subscript ùêπ ùúá ùúà \delta_{A,F}\mathcal{W}=\int d^{4}x\sqrt{-g}\left(J^{\mu}_{f}\,\delta A_{\mu}+\frac{1}{2}M^{\mu\nu}\delta F_{\mu\nu}\right)\,, italic_Œ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_W = ‚à´ italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x square-root start_ARG - italic_g end_ARG ( italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ¥ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ¥ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (21)

where J f Œº subscript superscript ùêΩ ùúá ùëì J^{\mu}_{f} italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the current of free charges and M Œº ŒΩ superscript ùëÄ ùúá ùúà M^{\mu\nu} italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the antisymmetric polarization tensor. In terms of these the total current can be written as

J Œº = J f Œº ‚àí ‚àá Œª M Œª Œº . superscript ùêΩ ùúá subscript superscript ùêΩ ùúá ùëì subscript ‚àá ùúÜ superscript ùëÄ ùúÜ ùúá J^{\mu}=J^{\mu}_{f}-\nabla_{\lambda}M^{\lambda\mu}. italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œª italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (22)

The ambiguity in defining the free charge current is fixed by choosing J f Œº = œÅ u Œº subscript superscript ùêΩ ùúá ùëì ùúå superscript ùë¢ ùúá J^{\mu}_{f}=\rho u^{\mu} italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_œÅ italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , with œÅ = ‚àÇ ‚Ñ± / ‚àÇ Œº ùúå ‚Ñ± ùúá \rho=\partial\mathcal{F}/\partial\mu italic_œÅ = ‚àÇ caligraphic_F / ‚àÇ italic_Œº being the free charge density. Comparing eqs.¬†( 11 ), ( 12 ) with eq.¬†( 22 ) above, we find the constitutive relations for the U ( 1 ) ùëà 1 U(1) italic_U ( 1 ) current to be

ùí© = œÅ ‚àí ‚àá ‚ãÖ p + p ‚ãÖ a ‚àí m ‚ãÖ Œ© , ùí© ùúå ‚ãÖ ‚àá ùëù ‚ãÖ ùëù ùëé ‚ãÖ ùëö Œ© \displaystyle\mathcal{N}=\rho-\nabla\cdot p+p\cdot a-m\cdot\Omega\,, caligraphic_N = italic_œÅ - ‚àá ‚ãÖ italic_p + italic_p ‚ãÖ italic_a - italic_m ‚ãÖ roman_Œ© , (23a)
ùí• Œº = œµ Œº ŒΩ œÅ œÉ u ŒΩ ( ‚àá œÅ + a œÅ ) m œÉ , superscript ùí• ùúá superscript italic-œµ ùúá ùúà ùúå ùúé subscript ùë¢ ùúà subscript ‚àá ùúå subscript ùëé ùúå subscript ùëö ùúé \displaystyle\mathcal{J}^{\mu}=\epsilon^{\mu\nu\rho\sigma}u_{\nu}\left(\nabla_{\rho}+a_{\rho}\right)m_{\sigma}\,, caligraphic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ italic_œÅ italic_œÉ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÉ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (23b)

p Œº = u ŒΩ M ŒΩ Œº , m Œº = 1 2 œµ Œº ŒΩ œÅ œÉ u ŒΩ M œÅ œÉ . formulae-sequence superscript ùëù ùúá subscript ùë¢ ùúà superscript ùëÄ ùúà ùúá superscript ùëö ùúá 1 2 superscript italic-œµ ùúá ùúà ùúå ùúé subscript ùë¢ ùúà subscript ùëÄ ùúå ùúé p^{\mu}=u_{\nu}M^{\nu\mu}\,,\quad m^{\mu}=\frac{1}{2}\epsilon^{\mu\nu\rho\sigma}u_{\nu}M_{\rho\sigma}. italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ italic_œÅ italic_œÉ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ italic_œÉ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (24)

For the first order generating functional eq.¬†( 17 ) we find the polarization vectors

m Œº = ( Œ± BB + 2 M Œ© , B 2 B ‚ãÖ Œ© ) B Œº + M Œ© Œ© Œº , superscript ùëö ùúá subscript ùõº BB ‚ãÖ 2 subscript ùëÄ Œ© superscript ùêµ 2 ùêµ Œ© superscript ùêµ ùúá subscript ùëÄ Œ© superscript Œ© ùúá \displaystyle m^{\mu}=\left(\alpha_{\rm BB}+2M_{\Omega,B^{2}}B\cdot\Omega\right)B^{\mu}+M_{\Omega}\Omega^{\mu}\,, italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_BB end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ© , italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B ‚ãÖ roman_Œ© ) italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ© start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (25b)

ùí© = n + ‚àÇ M Œ© ‚àÇ Œº B ‚ãÖ Œ© ‚àí m ‚ãÖ Œ© , ùí© ùëõ ‚ãÖ subscript ùëÄ Œ© ùúá ùêµ Œ© ‚ãÖ ùëö Œ© \displaystyle\mathcal{N}=n+\frac{\partial M_{\Omega}}{\partial\mu}B\cdot\Omega-m\cdot\Omega\,, caligraphic_N = italic_n + divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_Œº end_ARG italic_B ‚ãÖ roman_Œ© - italic_m ‚ãÖ roman_Œ© , (26a)

(26b)

3 Beyond thermal equilibrium

Let us now move on and introduce deviations from the state of thermal equilibrium introduced in section 2 . A comprehensive analysis of the out-of-equilibrium constitutive relations in the presence of a strong magnetic field appears in Hernandez:2017mch , which we shall make use of. It is important to notice that hydrodynamic variables such as the temperature, chemical potential or the fluid velocity have no a priori definition once one considers a state out of equilibrium. In other words, hydrodynamic variables are well defined only for a system in equilibrium. The freedom to choose a definition for hydrodynamic variables out of equilibrium, called a choice of hydrodynamic frame, can be used to fix some of the constitutive relations to a simple form. Following Hernandez:2017mch , we choose to work in the thermodynamic frame. In this frame, the freedom to choose the temperature T ùëá T italic_T and the chemical potential Œº ùúá \mu italic_Œº out of equilibrium can be used to fix ‚Ñ∞ ‚Ñ∞ \mathcal{E} caligraphic_E and ùí© ùí© \mathcal{N} caligraphic_N to their equilibrium values, given by eqs.¬†( 18a ) and ( 26a ). Also, the freedom to redefine the fluid velocity can be used to fix ùí¨ Œº superscript ùí¨ ùúá \mathcal{Q}^{\mu} caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to its equilibrium value ( 18c ). The other three quantities ùí´ , ùí• Œº ùí´ superscript ùí• ùúá \mathcal{P},\mathcal{J}^{\mu} caligraphic_P , caligraphic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ùíØ Œº ŒΩ superscript ùíØ ùúá ùúà \mathcal{T}^{\mu\nu} caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in the constitutive relations receive derivative corrections beyond their equilibrium values. The thermodynamic frame constitutive relations for ùí´ , ùí• Œº ùí´ superscript ùí• ùúá \mathcal{P},\mathcal{J}^{\mu} caligraphic_P , caligraphic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ùíØ Œº ŒΩ superscript ùíØ ùúá ùúà \mathcal{T}^{\mu\nu} caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with first-order derivative corrections out of equilibrium are given by

ùí´ = ùí´ ¬Ø ‚àí Œ∂ 1 ‚àá ‚ãÖ u ‚àí Œ∂ 2 b Œº b ŒΩ ‚àá Œº u ŒΩ , ùí´ ¬Ø ùí´ ‚ãÖ subscript ùúÅ 1 ‚àá ùë¢ subscript ùúÅ 2 superscript ùëè ùúá superscript ùëè ùúà subscript ‚àá ùúá subscript ùë¢ ùúà \displaystyle\mathcal{P}=\bar{\mathcal{P}}-\zeta_{1}\nabla\cdot u-\zeta_{2}\,b^{\mu}b^{\nu}\nabla_{\mu}u_{\nu}\,, caligraphic_P = over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_P end_ARG - italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àá ‚ãÖ italic_u - italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (27a)
ùíØ Œº ŒΩ = ùíØ ¬Ø Œº ŒΩ ‚àí Œ∑ ‚üÇ œÉ ‚üÇ Œº ŒΩ ‚àí Œ∑ ‚à• ( b Œº Œ£ ŒΩ + b ŒΩ Œ£ Œº ) ‚àí b ‚ü® Œº b ŒΩ ‚ü© ( Œ∑ 1 ‚àá ‚ãÖ u + Œ∑ 2 b Œ± b Œ≤ ‚àá Œ± u Œ≤ ) \displaystyle\mathcal{T}^{\mu\nu}=\bar{\mathcal{T}}^{\mu\nu}-\eta_{\perp}\sigma^{\mu\nu}_{\perp}-\eta_{\parallel}(b^{\mu}\Sigma^{\nu}+b^{\nu}\Sigma^{\mu})-b^{\langle\mu}b^{\nu\rangle}(\eta_{1}\nabla\cdot u+\eta_{2}b^{\alpha}b^{\beta}\nabla_{\alpha}u_{\beta}) caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_T end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ü® italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ ‚ü© end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àá ‚ãÖ italic_u + italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
‚àí Œ∑ ~ ‚üÇ œÉ ~ ‚üÇ Œº ŒΩ ‚àí Œ∑ ~ ‚à• ( b Œº Œ£ ~ ŒΩ + b ŒΩ Œ£ ~ Œº ) , subscript ~ ùúÇ perpendicular-to subscript superscript ~ ùúé ùúá ùúà perpendicular-to subscript ~ ùúÇ parallel-to superscript ùëè ùúá superscript ~ Œ£ ùúà superscript ùëè ùúà superscript ~ Œ£ ùúá \displaystyle\quad\quad-\tilde{\eta}_{\perp}\tilde{\sigma}^{\mu\nu}_{\perp}-\tilde{\eta}_{\parallel}(b^{\mu}\tilde{\Sigma}^{\nu}+b^{\nu}\tilde{\Sigma}^{\mu})\,, - over~ start_ARG italic_Œ∑ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_œÉ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over~ start_ARG italic_Œ∑ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG roman_Œ£ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG roman_Œ£ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (27b)
ùí• Œº = ùí• ¬Ø Œº + ( œÉ ‚üÇ ùîπ Œº ŒΩ + œÉ ‚à• B Œº B ŒΩ B 2 ) ùïç ŒΩ + œÉ ~ ùïç ~ Œº . superscript ùí• ùúá superscript ¬Ø ùí• ùúá subscript ùúé perpendicular-to superscript ùîπ ùúá ùúà subscript ùúé parallel-to superscript ùêµ ùúá superscript ùêµ ùúà superscript ùêµ 2 subscript ùïç ùúà ~ ùúé superscript ~ ùïç ùúá \displaystyle\mathcal{J}^{\mu}=\bar{\mathcal{J}}^{\mu}+\left(\sigma_{\perp}\mathbb{B}^{\mu\nu}+\sigma_{\parallel}\frac{B^{\mu}B^{\nu}}{B^{2}}\right)\mathbb{V}_{\nu}+\tilde{\sigma}\tilde{\mathbb{V}}^{\mu}. caligraphic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_J end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ( italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) blackboard_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + over~ start_ARG italic_œÉ end_ARG over~ start_ARG blackboard_V end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (27c)

Here ùí´ ¬Ø , ùí• ¬Ø Œº , ùíØ ¬Ø Œº ŒΩ ¬Ø ùí´ superscript ¬Ø ùí• ùúá superscript ¬Ø ùíØ ùúá ùúà \bar{\mathcal{P}},\bar{\mathcal{J}}^{\mu},\bar{\mathcal{T}}^{\mu\nu} over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_P end_ARG , over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_J end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , over¬Ø start_ARG caligraphic_T end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are the equilibrium values, given in eqs.¬†( 18b ), ( 26b ) and ( 18d ), respectively. Also, we have used the notation b Œº ‚â° B Œº / B 2 superscript ùëè ùúá superscript ùêµ ùúá superscript ùêµ 2 b^{\mu}\equiv B^{\mu}/\sqrt{B^{2}} italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â° italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / square-root start_ARG italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , and ùîπ Œº ŒΩ ‚â° Œî Œº ŒΩ ‚àí B Œº B ŒΩ B 2 superscript ùîπ ùúá ùúà superscript Œî ùúá ùúà superscript ùêµ ùúá superscript ùêµ ùúà superscript ùêµ 2 \mathbb{B}^{\mu\nu}\equiv\Delta^{\mu\nu}-\frac{B^{\mu}B^{\nu}}{B^{2}} blackboard_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â° roman_Œî start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG is the projector orthogonal to both u Œº superscript ùë¢ ùúá u^{\mu} italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and B Œº superscript ùêµ ùúá B^{\mu} italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . Also, we use the shorthand notation ùïç Œº ‚â° E Œº ‚àí T Œî Œº ŒΩ ‚àÇ ŒΩ ( Œº T ) superscript ùïç ùúá superscript ùê∏ ùúá ùëá superscript Œî ùúá ùúà subscript ùúà ùúá ùëá \mathbb{V}^{\mu}\equiv E^{\mu}-T\Delta^{\mu\nu}\partial_{\nu}\left(\frac{\mu}{T}\right) blackboard_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â° italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_T roman_Œî start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àÇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG italic_Œº end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ) , and ùïç ~ Œº = œµ Œº ŒΩ Œ± Œ≤ u ŒΩ b Œ± ùïç Œ≤ superscript ~ ùïç ùúá superscript italic-œµ ùúá ùúà ùõº ùõΩ subscript ùë¢ ùúà subscript ùëè ùõº subscript ùïç ùõΩ \tilde{\mathbb{V}}^{\mu}=\epsilon^{\mu\nu\alpha\beta}u_{\nu}b_{\alpha}\mathbb{V}_{\beta} over~ start_ARG blackboard_V end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ italic_Œ± italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . A decomposition similar to eq.¬†( 3 ) for the first-order out-of-equilibrium constitutive relations in the Landau frame appears in Huang:2011dc .

The shear tensor œÉ Œº ŒΩ superscript ùúé ùúá ùúà \sigma^{\mu\nu} italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , given by

œÉ Œº ŒΩ = Œî Œº Œ± Œî ŒΩ Œ≤ ( ‚àá Œ± u Œ≤ + ‚àá Œ≤ u Œ± ‚àí 2 3 g Œ± Œ≤ ‚àá ‚ãÖ u ) , superscript ùúé ùúá ùúà superscript Œî ùúá ùõº superscript Œî ùúà ùõΩ subscript ‚àá ùõº subscript ùë¢ ùõΩ subscript ‚àá ùõΩ subscript ùë¢ ùõº ‚ãÖ 2 3 subscript ùëî ùõº ùõΩ ‚àá ùë¢ \sigma^{\mu\nu}=\Delta^{\mu\alpha}\Delta^{\nu\beta}\left(\nabla_{\alpha}u_{\beta}+\nabla_{\beta}u_{\alpha}-\frac{2}{3}\,g_{\alpha\beta}\nabla\cdot u\right), italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_Œî start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_Œ± end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Œî start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àá ‚ãÖ italic_u ) ,

has been decomposed as

œÉ Œº ŒΩ = œÉ ‚üÇ Œº ŒΩ + ( b Œº Œ£ ŒΩ + b ŒΩ Œ£ Œº ) + 1 2 b ‚ü® Œº b ŒΩ ‚ü© ( 3 b Œ± b Œ≤ ‚àá Œ± u Œ≤ ‚àí ‚àá ‚ãÖ u ) . \sigma^{\mu\nu}=\sigma^{\mu\nu}_{\perp}+\left(b^{\mu}\Sigma^{\nu}+b^{\nu}\Sigma^{\mu}\right)+\frac{1}{2}b^{\langle\mu}b^{\nu\rangle}(3b^{\alpha}b^{\beta}\nabla_{\alpha}u_{\beta}-\nabla\cdot u). italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ü® italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ ‚ü© end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 3 italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ‚àá ‚ãÖ italic_u ) .
