Here œÉ ‚üÇ Œº ŒΩ subscript superscript ùúé ùúá ùúà perpendicular-to \sigma^{\mu\nu}_{\perp} italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is transverse to both u Œº superscript ùë¢ ùúá u^{\mu} italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and B Œº superscript ùêµ ùúá B^{\mu} italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

Similarly, Œ£ Œº ‚â° ùîπ Œº Œ± œÉ Œ± Œ≤ b Œ≤ superscript Œ£ ùúá superscript ùîπ ùúá ùõº subscript ùúé ùõº ùõΩ superscript ùëè ùõΩ \Sigma^{\mu}\equiv\mathbb{B}^{\mu\alpha}\sigma_{\alpha\beta}b^{\beta} roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚â° blackboard_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_Œ± end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is also transverse to both u Œº superscript ùë¢ ùúá u^{\mu} italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and B Œº superscript ùêµ ùúá B^{\mu} italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

The tensor œÉ ~ Œº ŒΩ superscript ~ ùúé ùúá ùúà \tilde{\sigma}^{\mu\nu} over~ start_ARG italic_œÉ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is another rank-two one-derivative tensor that enters the constitutive relations above. It is given by

œÉ ~ Œº ŒΩ = 1 2 B 2 ( œµ Œº œÅ Œ± Œ≤ u œÅ B Œ± œÉ Œ≤ ŒΩ + œµ ŒΩ œÅ Œ± Œ≤ u œÅ B Œ± œÉ Œ≤ Œº ) . superscript ~ ùúé ùúá ùúà 1 2 superscript ùêµ 2 superscript italic-œµ ùúá ùúå ùõº ùõΩ subscript ùë¢ ùúå subscript ùêµ ùõº superscript subscript ùúé ùõΩ ùúà superscript italic-œµ ùúà ùúå ùõº ùõΩ subscript ùë¢ ùúå subscript ùêµ ùõº superscript subscript ùúé ùõΩ ùúá \tilde{\sigma}^{\mu\nu}=\frac{1}{2\sqrt{B^{2}}}\left(\epsilon^{\mu\rho\alpha\beta}u_{\rho}B_{\alpha}\sigma_{\beta}^{\,\,\nu}+\epsilon^{\nu\rho\alpha\beta}u_{\rho}B_{\alpha}\sigma_{\beta}^{\,\,\mu}\right). over~ start_ARG italic_œÉ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 square-root start_ARG italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG ( italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_œÅ italic_Œ± italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ italic_œÅ italic_Œ± italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÅ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (29)

Inserting the decomposition eq.¬†( 28 ) for œÉ Œº ŒΩ superscript ùúé ùúá ùúà \sigma^{\mu\nu} italic_œÉ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT into eq.¬†( 29 ), one gets

œÉ ~ Œº ŒΩ = œÉ ~ ‚üÇ Œº ŒΩ + ( b Œº Œ£ ~ ŒΩ + b ŒΩ Œ£ ~ Œº ) , superscript ~ ùúé ùúá ùúà subscript superscript ~ ùúé ùúá ùúà perpendicular-to superscript ùëè ùúá superscript ~ Œ£ ùúà superscript ùëè ùúà superscript ~ Œ£ ùúá \tilde{\sigma}^{\mu\nu}=\tilde{\sigma}^{\mu\nu}_{\perp}+\left(b^{\mu}\tilde{\Sigma}^{\nu}+b^{\nu}\tilde{\Sigma}^{\mu}\right), over~ start_ARG italic_œÉ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = over~ start_ARG italic_œÉ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG roman_Œ£ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG roman_Œ£ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (30)

where

œÉ ~ ‚üÇ Œº ŒΩ = 1 2 ( ùîπ Œº Œ± ùîπ ŒΩ Œ≤ + ùîπ Œº Œ≤ ùîπ ŒΩ Œ± ‚àí ùîπ Œº ŒΩ ùîπ Œ± Œ≤ ) œÉ ~ Œ± Œ≤ , subscript superscript ~ ùúé ùúá ùúà perpendicular-to 1 2 superscript ùîπ ùúá ùõº superscript ùîπ ùúà ùõΩ superscript ùîπ ùúá ùõΩ superscript ùîπ ùúà ùõº superscript ùîπ ùúá ùúà superscript ùîπ ùõº ùõΩ subscript ~ ùúé ùõº ùõΩ \tilde{\sigma}^{\mu\nu}_{\perp}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\mathbb{B}^{\mu\alpha}\mathbb{B}^{\nu\beta}+\mathbb{B}^{\mu\beta}\mathbb{B}^{\nu\alpha}-\mathbb{B}^{\mu\nu}\mathbb{B}^{\alpha\beta}\right)\tilde{\sigma}_{\alpha\beta}\,, over~ start_ARG italic_œÉ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( blackboard_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_Œ± end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + blackboard_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ŒΩ italic_Œ± end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - blackboard_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_ŒΩ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ± italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) over~ start_ARG italic_œÉ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

and Œ£ ~ Œº = ùîπ Œº Œ± œÉ ~ Œ± Œ≤ b Œ≤ superscript ~ Œ£ ùúá superscript ùîπ ùúá ùõº subscript ~ ùúé ùõº ùõΩ superscript ùëè ùõΩ \tilde{\Sigma}^{\mu}=\mathbb{B}^{\mu\alpha}\tilde{\sigma}_{\alpha\beta}b^{\beta} over~ start_ARG roman_Œ£ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = blackboard_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº italic_Œ± end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_œÉ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

The first-order out-of-equilibrium transport parameters appearing in the constitutive relations eq.¬†( 3 ) are not all dissipative. In general, every dissipative transport parameter is necessarily an out-of-equilibrium contribution, but every out-of-equilibrium parameter is not necessarily dissipative. The eleven transport parameters appearing in eq.¬†( 3 ) can be classified as follows.

Parameter Name Nature
Œ∑ ‚üÇ subscript ùúÇ perpendicular-to \eta_{\perp} italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Transverse shear viscosity Dissipative
Œ∑ ‚à• subscript ùúÇ parallel-to \eta_{\parallel} italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Longitudinal shear viscosity Dissipative
œÉ ‚üÇ subscript ùúé perpendicular-to \sigma_{\perp} italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Transverse conductivity Dissipative
œÉ ‚à• subscript ùúé parallel-to \sigma_{\parallel} italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Longitudinal conductivity Dissipative
Œ∂ 1 , Œ∂ 2 , Œ∑ 1 , Œ∑ 2 subscript ùúÅ 1 subscript ùúÅ 2 subscript ùúÇ 1 subscript ùúÇ 2 \zeta_{1},\zeta_{2},\eta_{1},\eta_{2} italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Bulk viscosities Dissipative
Œ∑ ~ ‚üÇ subscript ~ ùúÇ perpendicular-to \tilde{\eta}_{\perp} over~ start_ARG italic_Œ∑ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Transverse Hall viscosity Non-diss.
Œ∑ ~ ‚à• subscript ~ ùúÇ parallel-to \tilde{\eta}_{\parallel} over~ start_ARG italic_Œ∑ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Longitudinal Hall viscosity Non-diss.
œÉ ~ ~ ùúé \tilde{\sigma} over~ start_ARG italic_œÉ end_ARG Hall conductivity Non-diss.

An important point to note is that not all of the four bulk viscosities are independent. The time reversal invariance of the underlying microscopic theory imposes an Onsager relation on the bulk viscosities above, and gives the constraint

3 Œ∂ 2 ‚àí 6 Œ∑ 1 ‚àí 2 Œ∑ 2 = 0 . 3 subscript ùúÅ 2 6 subscript ùúÇ 1 2 subscript ùúÇ 2 0 3\zeta_{2}-6\eta_{1}-2\eta_{2}=0. 3 italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 6 italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 2 italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 . (31)

Thus, the number of independent out-of-equilibrium transport parameters at one-derivative order is ten. Also, if one assumes the fluid to be conformal, then the bulk viscosities Œ∂ 1 = Œ∂ 2 = 0 subscript ùúÅ 1 subscript ùúÅ 2 0 \zeta_{1}=\zeta_{2}=0 italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 .

4 Linearized hydrodynamics

We now move on to study the behaviour of small fluctuations and their correlation functions about a state of thermal equilibrium, which is the main thrust of this paper. The equilibrium state we consider coincides with the fluid at rest u 0 Œº = ( 1 , ùüé ) subscript superscript ùë¢ ùúá 0 1 0 u^{\mu}_{0}=(1,\boldsymbol{0}) italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 , bold_0 ) , at a constant global temperature T 0 subscript ùëá 0 T_{0} italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and chemical potential Œº 0 subscript ùúá 0 \mu_{0} italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . The equilibrium energy density is œµ 0 subscript italic-œµ 0 \epsilon_{0} italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , pressure p 0 subscript ùëù 0 p_{0} italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and charge density n 0 subscript ùëõ 0 n_{0} italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . The background magnetic field can be taken to point along the + Z ùëç +Z + italic_Z direction without any loss of generality, so B Œº = ( 0 , 0 , 0 , B 0 ) superscript ùêµ ùúá 0 0 0 subscript ùêµ 0 B^{\mu}=(0,0,0,B_{0}) italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( 0 , 0 , 0 , italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . All other background sources are turned off. We work with fluctuations in the energy density Œ¥ œµ ùõø italic-œµ \delta\epsilon italic_Œ¥ italic_œµ , charge density Œ¥ n ùõø ùëõ \delta n italic_Œ¥ italic_n , and momentum density œÄ i superscript ùúã ùëñ \pi^{i} italic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . These are defined via

T 00 = œµ 0 + Œ¥ œµ + ‚Ä¶ , T 0 i = œÄ i + ‚Ä¶ , J 0 = n 0 + Œ¥ n + ‚Ä¶ , formulae-sequence superscript ùëá 00 subscript italic-œµ 0 ùõø italic-œµ ‚Ä¶ formulae-sequence superscript ùëá 0 ùëñ superscript ùúã ùëñ ‚Ä¶ superscript ùêΩ 0 subscript ùëõ 0 ùõø ùëõ ‚Ä¶ \begin{split}&T^{00}=\epsilon_{0}+\delta\epsilon+\ldots\,,\\ &T^{0i}=\pi^{i}+\ldots\,,\\ &J^{0}=n_{0}+\delta n+\ldots\,,\end{split} start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 00 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ¥ italic_œµ + ‚Ä¶ , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ‚Ä¶ , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ¥ italic_n + ‚Ä¶ , end_CELL end_ROW (32)

where the ‚Ä¶ ‚Ä¶ \ldots ‚Ä¶ in the expressions above denote terms which depend upon the background magnetic field B 0 subscript ùêµ 0 B_{0} italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . Note that the momentum density fluctuations are related to the velocity fluctuations via œÄ i = ( œµ 0 + p 0 ) Œ¥ u i = w 0 Œ¥ u i superscript ùúã ùëñ subscript italic-œµ 0 subscript ùëù 0 ùõø superscript ùë¢ ùëñ subscript ùë§ 0 ùõø superscript ùë¢ ùëñ \pi^{i}=(\epsilon_{0}+p_{0})\delta u^{i}=w_{0}\delta u^{i} italic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_Œ¥ italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ¥ italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , where w 0 = œµ 0 + p 0 subscript ùë§ 0 subscript italic-œµ 0 subscript ùëù 0 w_{0}=\epsilon_{0}+p_{0} italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the equilibrium enthalpy density.

Using the thermodynamic frame constitutive relations for the energy-momentum tensor and the conserved current discussed in sections 2 and 3 , one can write down the hydrodynamic equations ( 2 ) to linear order in the fluctuations Œ¥ n , Œ¥ œµ , œÄ i ùõø ùëõ ùõø italic-œµ superscript ùúã ùëñ \delta n,\delta\epsilon,\pi^{i} italic_Œ¥ italic_n , italic_Œ¥ italic_œµ , italic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT about the chosen state of equilibrium. The full set of linearized equations about the equilibrium state of interest are presented in A .

The primary reason to work out the linearized fluctuation equations is to be able to make use of linear response theory, which would allow us to obtain retarded correlation functions of the fluctuations about the given state of equilibrium. As per the linear response approach, for a set of hydrodynamic variables Œ¶ A ( t , ùê± ) subscript Œ¶ A ùë° ùê± \Phi_{\rm A}(t,{\bf x}) roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t , bold_x ) satisfying coupled linear equations in momentum space of the form

‚àÇ t Œ¶ A ( t , ùê§ ) + ùïÑ AB ( ùê§ ) Œ¶ B ( t , ùê§ ) = 0 , subscript ùë° subscript Œ¶ A ùë° ùê§ subscript ùïÑ AB ùê§ subscript Œ¶ B ùë° ùê§ 0 \partial_{t}\Phi_{\rm A}(t,{\bf{k}})+\mathbb{M}_{\rm AB}({\bf k})\,\Phi_{\rm B}(t,{\bf k})=0, ‚àÇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t , bold_k ) + blackboard_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_AB end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_k ) roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t , bold_k ) = 0 , (33)

the retarded two-point correlation functions are given by 5 5 5 The retarded and symmetric correlation functions are defined via ùîæ ùí™ 1 ùí™ 2 Ret ( t 1 ‚àí t 2 , ùê± 1 ‚àí ùê± 2 ) ‚â° ‚àí i Œò ( t 1 ‚àí t 2 ) ‚ü® [ ùí™ 1 ( t 1 , ùê± 1 ) , ùí™ 2 ( t 2 , ùê± 2 ) ] ‚ü© , subscript superscript ùîæ Ret subscript ùí™ 1 subscript ùí™ 2 subscript ùë° 1 subscript ùë° 2 subscript ùê± 1 subscript ùê± 2 ùëñ Œò subscript ùë° 1 subscript ùë° 2 delimited-‚ü®‚ü© subscript ùí™ 1 subscript ùë° 1 subscript ùê± 1 subscript ùí™ 2 subscript ùë° 2 subscript ùê± 2 \displaystyle\mathbb{G}^{\rm Ret}_{\mathcal{O}_{1}\mathcal{O}_{2}}(t_{1}-t_{2},{\bf x}_{1}-{\bf x}_{2})\equiv-i\Theta(t_{1}-t_{2})\langle[\mathcal{O}_{1}(t_{1},{\bf x}_{1}),\mathcal{O}_{2}(t_{2},{\bf x}_{2})]\rangle, blackboard_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Ret end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚â° - italic_i roman_Œò ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚ü® [ caligraphic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , caligraphic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] ‚ü© , ùîæ ùí™ 1 ùí™ 2 Sym ( t 1 ‚àí t 2 , ùê± 1 ‚àí ùê± 2 ) ‚â° 1 2 ‚ü® { ùí™ 1 ( t 1 , ùê± 1 ) , ùí™ 2 ( t 2 , ùê± 2 ) } ‚ü© , subscript superscript ùîæ Sym subscript ùí™ 1 subscript ùí™ 2 subscript ùë° 1 subscript ùë° 2 subscript ùê± 1 subscript ùê± 2 1 2 delimited-‚ü®‚ü© subscript ùí™ 1 subscript ùë° 1 subscript ùê± 1 subscript ùí™ 2 subscript ùë° 2 subscript ùê± 2 \displaystyle\mathbb{G}^{\rm Sym}_{\mathcal{O}_{1}\mathcal{O}_{2}}(t_{1}-t_{2},{\bf x}_{1}-{\bf x}_{2})\equiv\frac{1}{2}\langle\{\mathcal{O}_{1}(t_{1},{\bf x}_{1}),\mathcal{O}_{2}(t_{2},{\bf x}_{2})\}\rangle, blackboard_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Sym end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚â° divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚ü® { caligraphic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , caligraphic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } ‚ü© , where Œò ( t ) Œò ùë° \Theta(t) roman_Œò ( italic_t ) is the step function, and square and curly braces respectively denote a commutator and an anticommutator.

ùîæ Ret ( œâ , ùê§ ) = ‚àí ( ùüè + i œâ ùïÇ ‚àí 1 ) ùùå , superscript ùîæ Ret ùúî ùê§ 1 ùëñ ùúî superscript ùïÇ 1 ùùå \mathbb{G}^{\rm Ret}(\omega,{\bf k})=-\left(\boldsymbol{1}+i\omega\mathbb{K}^{-1}\right)\boldsymbol{\chi}, blackboard_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Ret end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_œâ , bold_k ) = - ( bold_1 + italic_i italic_œâ blackboard_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) bold_italic_œá , (34)

where the matrix ùïÇ = ‚àí i œâ ùüè + ùïÑ ( ùê§ ) ùïÇ ùëñ ùúî 1 ùïÑ ùê§ \mathbb{K}=-i\omega\boldsymbol{1}+\mathbb{M}({\bf k}) blackboard_K = - italic_i italic_œâ bold_1 + blackboard_M ( bold_k ) . Also, if the sources for the hydrodynamic fluctuations Œ¶ A subscript Œ¶ ùê¥ \Phi_{A} roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are œï A subscript italic-œï ùê¥ \phi_{A} italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , then the susceptibility matrix ùùå ùùå \boldsymbol{\chi} bold_italic_œá is given by

ùùå AB = ‚àÇ Œ¶ A ‚àÇ œï B . subscript ùùå AB subscript Œ¶ ùê¥ subscript italic-œï ùêµ \boldsymbol{\chi}_{\rm AB}=\frac{\partial\Phi_{A}}{\partial\phi_{B}}. bold_italic_œá start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_AB end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG ‚àÇ roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG . (35)

The matrix ùùå ùùå \boldsymbol{\chi} bold_italic_œá has been computed in B . Linear response theory is thus good enough if one is interested only in the causal linear response of the system to external sources. However, the richness of hydrodynamics is contained in the nonlinear nature of its equations, and we explore some of their consequences in section 5 below.

Making use of the linear response approach outlined above, in principle one can work with the entire set of transport parameters that appear at the first-order and compute the linear response of the system following from the hydrodynamic equations in A . However, this is quite cumbersome and not analytically tractable. A simpler strategy is to compute the linear response when one of the first-order transport parameters dominates over the rest. In such a scenario, one can assume that it is only this transport parameter that is non-zero, while the rest are set to vanish. This approximation of dealing with a single transport parameter and its effects on the system at a given time renders the setup analytically tractable. Needless to say, one can work with all or any other suitable subset of non-zero transport parameters depending upon the situation of interest. However, this will inevitably require the use of numerical approaches to the problem, which we leave out for a future study.

In section 5 below, we will illustrate the effect of non-linearities and the emergence of long-time tails for the two cases when the dissipative viscosities Œ∑ ‚à• subscript ùúÇ parallel-to \eta_{\parallel} italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Œ∂ 1 subscript ùúÅ 1 \zeta_{1} italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the ones that dominate the transport and relaxation process. We make this choice for the relative simplicity of the equations and loop-computations that follow. Further, it is useful to assume that we are working with a fluid which is perturbed around a neutral state i.e. n 0 = 0 subscript ùëõ 0 0 n_{0}=0 italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 . With this in mind, we now move on to compute the linear response and the associated retarded correlation functions for the two cases of interest.

4.1 Linear response when only Œ∑ ‚à• ‚â† 0 subscript ùúÇ parallel-to 0 \eta_{\parallel}\neq 0 italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â† 0

We first consider the case when the dominant transport parameter is the shear viscosity Œ∑ ‚à• subscript ùúÇ parallel-to \eta_{\parallel} italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , and the other transport parameters are negligibly small. Since we are interested in the shear modes, an additional simplification one can impose is the assumption of incompressibility, ‚àÇ i œÄ i ‚âà 0 subscript ùëñ superscript ùúã ùëñ 0 \partial_{i}\pi^{i}\approx 0 ‚àÇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚âà 0 , which decouples the sound modes of the system and further simplifies the coupled equations in A . In fact, with these simplifications put in, the energy density and charge density fluctuations decouple from the velocity fluctuations, leaving behind a much simpler system of equations to be analyzed for the shear modes. Linear response theory then leads to the following set of retarded two-point correlators.

ùîæ œÄ x œÄ x Ret ( œâ , ùê§ ) = Œ∑ ‚à• k ‚à• 2 [ i œâ ‚àí Œ∑ ‚à• w 0 ( k 2 ‚àí k x 2 ) ] F 1 ( œâ , k ‚à• ) F 2 ( œâ , k ) , subscript superscript ùîæ Ret subscript ùúã ùë• subscript ùúã ùë• ùúî ùê§ subscript ùúÇ parallel-to superscript subscript ùëò parallel-to 2 delimited-[] ùëñ ùúî subscript ùúÇ parallel-to subscript ùë§ 0 superscript ùëò 2 superscript subscript ùëò ùë• 2 subscript ùêπ 1 ùúî subscript ùëò parallel-to subscript ùêπ 2 ùúî ùëò \displaystyle\mathbb{G}^{\rm Ret}_{\pi_{x}\pi_{x}}(\omega,{\bf k})=\frac{\eta_{\parallel}k_{\parallel}^{2}\left[i\omega-\frac{\eta_{\parallel}}{w_{0}}(k^{2}-k_{x}^{2})\right]}{{F}_{1}(\omega,k_{\parallel})\,F_{2}(\omega,k)}, blackboard_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Ret end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ , bold_k ) = divide start_ARG italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_i italic_œâ - divide start_ARG italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] end_ARG start_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ , italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ , italic_k ) end_ARG , (36a)
ùîæ œÄ y œÄ y Ret ( œâ , ùê§ ) = Œ∑ ‚à• k ‚à• 2 [ i œâ ‚àí Œ∑ ‚à• w 0 ( k 2 ‚àí k y 2 ) ] F 1 ( œâ , k ‚à• ) F 2 ( œâ , k ) , subscript superscript ùîæ Ret subscript ùúã ùë¶ subscript ùúã ùë¶ ùúî ùê§ subscript ùúÇ parallel-to superscript subscript ùëò parallel-to 2 delimited-[] ùëñ ùúî subscript ùúÇ parallel-to subscript ùë§ 0 superscript ùëò 2 superscript subscript ùëò ùë¶ 2 subscript ùêπ 1 ùúî subscript ùëò parallel-to subscript ùêπ 2 ùúî ùëò \displaystyle\mathbb{G}^{\rm Ret}_{\pi_{y}\pi_{y}}(\omega,{\bf k})=\frac{\eta_{\parallel}k_{\parallel}^{2}\left[i\omega-\frac{\eta_{\parallel}}{w_{0}}(k^{2}-k_{y}^{2})\right]}{F_{1}(\omega,k_{\parallel})\,F_{2}(\omega,k)}, blackboard_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Ret end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ , bold_k ) = divide start_ARG italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_i italic_œâ - divide start_ARG italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] end_ARG start_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ , italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ , italic_k ) end_ARG , (36b)
ùîæ œÄ z œÄ z Ret ( œâ , ùê§ ) = Œ∑ ‚à• k ‚üÇ 2 F 2 ( œâ , k ) , subscript superscript ùîæ Ret subscript ùúã ùëß subscript ùúã ùëß ùúî ùê§ subscript ùúÇ parallel-to superscript subscript ùëò perpendicular-to 2 subscript ùêπ 2 ùúî ùëò \displaystyle\mathbb{G}^{\rm Ret}_{\pi_{z}\pi_{z}}(\omega,{\bf k})=\frac{\eta_{\parallel}k_{\perp}^{2}}{F_{2}(\omega,k)}, blackboard_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Ret end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ , bold_k ) = divide start_ARG italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ , italic_k ) end_ARG , (36c)

ùîæ œÄ x œÄ z Ret ( œâ , ùê§ ) = Œ∑ ‚à• k x k z F 2 ( œâ , k ) , subscript superscript ùîæ Ret subscript ùúã ùë• subscript ùúã ùëß ùúî ùê§ subscript ùúÇ parallel-to subscript ùëò ùë• subscript ùëò ùëß subscript ùêπ 2 ùúî ùëò \displaystyle\mathbb{G}^{\rm Ret}_{\pi_{x}\pi_{z}}(\omega,{\bf k})=\frac{\eta_{\parallel}k_{x}k_{z}}{F_{2}(\omega,k)}, blackboard_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Ret end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ , bold_k ) = divide start_ARG italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ , italic_k ) end_ARG , (36e)
ùîæ œÄ y œÄ z Ret ( œâ , ùê§ ) = Œ∑ ‚à• k y k z F 2 ( œâ , k ) , subscript superscript ùîæ Ret subscript ùúã ùë¶ subscript ùúã ùëß ùúî ùê§ subscript ùúÇ parallel-to subscript ùëò ùë¶ subscript ùëò ùëß subscript ùêπ 2 ùúî ùëò \displaystyle\mathbb{G}^{\rm Ret}_{\pi_{y}\pi_{z}}(\omega,{\bf k})=\frac{\eta_{\parallel}k_{y}k_{z}}{F_{2}(\omega,k)}, blackboard_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Ret end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ , bold_k ) = divide start_ARG italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ , italic_k ) end_ARG , (36f)

where

F 1 ( œâ , k ‚à• ) = i œâ ‚àí Œ∑ ‚à• w 0 k ‚à• 2 , subscript ùêπ 1 ùúî subscript ùëò parallel-to ùëñ ùúî subscript ùúÇ parallel-to subscript ùë§ 0 superscript subscript ùëò parallel-to 2 \displaystyle{F}_{1}(\omega,k_{\parallel})=i\omega-\frac{\eta_{\parallel}}{w_{0}}k_{\parallel}^{2}, italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ , italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_i italic_œâ - divide start_ARG italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,
F 2 ( œâ , k ) = i œâ ‚àí Œ∑ ‚à• w 0 k 2 . subscript ùêπ 2 ùúî ùëò ùëñ ùúî subscript ùúÇ parallel-to subscript ùë§ 0 superscript ùëò 2 \displaystyle F_{2}(\omega,k)=i\omega-\frac{\eta_{\parallel}}{w_{0}}k^{2}. italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ , italic_k ) = italic_i italic_œâ - divide start_ARG italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Note that since the magnetic field points along the + Z ùëç +Z + italic_Z direction, in the above we have made use of the intuitive notation k ‚à• ‚â° k z , k ‚üÇ = k x 2 + k y 2 , k ‚â° | ùê§ | formulae-sequence subscript ùëò parallel-to subscript ùëò ùëß formulae-sequence subscript ùëò perpendicular-to superscript subscript ùëò ùë• 2 superscript subscript ùëò ùë¶ 2 ùëò ùê§ k_{\parallel}\equiv k_{z},k_{\perp}=\sqrt{k_{x}^{2}+k_{y}^{2}},\,k\equiv|{\bf k}| italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â° italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = square-root start_ARG italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , italic_k ‚â° | bold_k | .

4.2 Linear response when only Œ∂ 1 ‚â† 0 subscript ùúÅ 1 0 \zeta_{1}\neq 0 italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â† 0

This is the second of the cases we will consider, when the bulk viscosity Œ∂ 1 subscript ùúÅ 1 \zeta_{1} italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the dominant transport parameter, while the rest are negligibly smaller. The set of non-vanishing retarded two-point functions for this case that arise from linear response theory are as follows.

ùîæ œµ œµ ret ( œâ , ùê§ ) = w 0 k 2 ( œâ ‚àí œâ + ) ( œâ ‚àí œâ ‚àí ) , subscript superscript ùîæ ret italic-œµ italic-œµ ùúî ùê§ subscript ùë§ 0 superscript ùëò 2 ùúî subscript ùúî ùúî subscript ùúî \displaystyle\mathbb{G}^{\rm ret}_{\epsilon\epsilon}(\omega,{\bf k})=\frac{w_{0}k^{2}}{(\omega-\omega_{+})(\omega-\omega_{-})}\,, blackboard_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ret end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œµ italic_œµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ , bold_k ) = divide start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_œâ - italic_œâ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_œâ - italic_œâ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG , (38a)
ùîæ œµ œÄ i ret ( œâ , ùê§ ) = w 0 œâ k i ( œâ ‚àí œâ + ) ( œâ ‚àí œâ ‚àí ) , subscript superscript ùîæ ret italic-œµ subscript ùúã ùëñ ùúî ùê§ subscript ùë§ 0 ùúî subscript ùëò ùëñ ùúî subscript ùúî ùúî subscript ùúî \displaystyle\mathbb{G}^{\rm ret}_{\epsilon\pi_{i}}(\omega,{\bf k})=\frac{w_{0}\,\omega\,k_{i}}{(\omega-\omega_{+})(\omega-\omega_{-})}\,, blackboard_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ret end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œµ italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ , bold_k ) = divide start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œâ italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_œâ - italic_œâ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_œâ - italic_œâ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG , (38b)
ùîæ œÄ x œÄ x ret ( œâ , ùê§ ) = k x 2 ( w 0 v s 2 ‚àí i œâ Œ∂ 1 ) ( œâ ‚àí œâ + ) ( œâ ‚àí œâ ‚àí ) , subscript superscript ùîæ ret subscript ùúã ùë• subscript ùúã ùë• ùúî ùê§ superscript subscript ùëò ùë• 2 subscript ùë§ 0 superscript subscript ùë£ ùë† 2 ùëñ ùúî subscript ùúÅ 1 ùúî subscript ùúî ùúî subscript ùúî \displaystyle\mathbb{G}^{\rm ret}_{\pi_{x}\pi_{x}}(\omega,{\bf k})=\frac{k_{x}^{2}\left(w_{0}v_{s}^{2}-i\omega\zeta_{1}\right)}{(\omega-\omega_{+})(\omega-\omega_{-})}\,, blackboard_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ret end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ , bold_k ) = divide start_ARG italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_i italic_œâ italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_œâ - italic_œâ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_œâ - italic_œâ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG , (38c)

ùîæ œÄ y œÄ z ret ( œâ , ùê§ ) = k y k z ( w 0 v s 2 ‚àí i œâ Œ∂ 1 ) ( œâ ‚àí œâ + ) ( œâ ‚àí œâ ‚àí ) , subscript superscript ùîæ ret subscript ùúã ùë¶ subscript ùúã ùëß ùúî ùê§ subscript ùëò ùë¶ subscript ùëò ùëß subscript ùë§ 0 superscript subscript ùë£ ùë† 2 ùëñ ùúî subscript ùúÅ 1 ùúî subscript ùúî ùúî subscript ùúî \displaystyle\mathbb{G}^{\rm ret}_{\pi_{y}\pi_{z}}(\omega,{\bf k})=\frac{k_{y}k_{z}\left(w_{0}v_{s}^{2}-i\omega\zeta_{1}\right)}{(\omega-\omega_{+})(\omega-\omega_{-})}\,, blackboard_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ret end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ , bold_k ) = divide start_ARG italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_i italic_œâ italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_œâ - italic_œâ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_œâ - italic_œâ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG , (38h)

where œâ ¬± subscript ùúî plus-or-minus \omega_{\pm} italic_œâ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ¬± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the two sound modes, given by

œâ ¬± = ¬± v s k ‚àí i Œ∂ 1 2 w 0 k 2 . subscript ùúî plus-or-minus plus-or-minus subscript ùë£ ùë† ùëò ùëñ subscript ùúÅ 1 2 subscript ùë§ 0 superscript ùëò 2 \omega_{\pm}=\pm v_{s}k-i\frac{\zeta_{1}}{2w_{0}}k^{2}. italic_œâ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ¬± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ¬± italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - italic_i divide start_ARG italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Note that v s subscript ùë£ ùë† v_{s} italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the speed of sound, which in the neutral equilibrium state of interest is given by v s 2 = ( ‚àÇ p / ‚àÇ œµ ) superscript subscript ùë£ ùë† 2 ùëù italic-œµ v_{s}^{2}=(\partial p/\partial\epsilon) italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( ‚àÇ italic_p / ‚àÇ italic_œµ ) .

5 Interactions and long-time tails

With the retarded correlation functions in hand, we now move on to compute the long-time tails, and their dependence on the viscosities Œ∑ ‚à• , Œ∂ 1 subscript ùúÇ parallel-to subscript ùúÅ 1 \eta_{\parallel},\zeta_{1} italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . As we have mentioned earlier, the long-time tails are a consequence of the nonlinear terms in the hydrodynamic constitutive relations, which correspond to interactions between the fluctuating degrees of freedom. The leading long-time tails will come from the leading nonlinear terms in the energy-momentum tensor eq.¬†( 2.1.2 ), which have the form

T i j = Œ¥ i j ( Œ• 1 Œ¥ œµ 2 + Œ• 2 Œ¥ n 2 ‚àí v s 2 w 0 ùùÖ 2 + 1 2 Œ± BB B 0 2 w 0 2 œÄ z 2 ) + ( w 0 ‚àí Œ± BB B 0 2 ) œÄ i œÄ j w 0 2 superscript ùëá ùëñ ùëó superscript ùõø ùëñ ùëó subscript Œ• 1 ùõø superscript italic-œµ 2 subscript Œ• 2 ùõø superscript ùëõ 2 superscript subscript ùë£ ùë† 2 subscript ùë§ 0 superscript ùùÖ 2 1 2 subscript ùõº BB superscript subscript ùêµ 0 2 superscript subscript ùë§ 0 2 superscript subscript ùúã ùëß 2 subscript ùë§ 0 subscript ùõº BB superscript subscript ùêµ 0 2 superscript ùúã ùëñ superscript ùúã ùëó superscript subscript ùë§ 0 2 \displaystyle T^{ij}=\delta^{ij}\left(\Upsilon_{1}\,\delta\epsilon^{2}+\Upsilon_{2}\,\delta n^{2}-\frac{v_{s}^{2}}{w_{0}}{\boldsymbol{\pi}}^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\frac{\alpha_{\rm BB}B_{0}^{2}}{w_{0}^{2}}\pi_{z}^{2}\right)+\left(w_{0}-\alpha_{\rm BB}B_{0}^{2}\right)\frac{\pi^{i}\pi^{j}}{w_{0}^{2}} italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Œ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_Œ• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ¥ italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Œ• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ¥ italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG bold_italic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG divide start_ARG italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_BB end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - + ( Œ± B B ‚àí M Œ© , Œº ) B 0 2 w 0 2 [ œÄ x ( Œ¥ i x œÄ j + Œ¥ j x œÄ i ) + œÄ y ( Œ¥ i y œÄ j + Œ¥ j y œÄ i ) ] + ‚ãØ subscript ùõº ùêµ ùêµ subscript ùëÄ Œ© ùúá superscript subscript ùêµ 0 2 superscript subscript ùë§ 0 2 delimited-[] subscript ùúã ùë• superscript ùõø ùëñ ùë• superscript ùúã ùëó superscript ùõø ùëó ùë• superscript ùúã ùëñ subscript ùúã ùë¶ superscript ùõø ùëñ ùë¶ superscript ùúã ùëó superscript ùõø ùëó ùë¶ superscript ùúã ùëñ ‚ãØ \displaystyle\qquad+\left(\alpha_{BB}-M_{\Omega,\mu}\right)\frac{B_{0}^{2}}{w_{0}^{2}}\left[\pi_{x}(\delta^{ix}\pi^{j}+\delta^{jx}\pi^{i})+\pi_{y}(\delta^{iy}\pi^{j}+\delta^{jy}\pi^{i})\right]+\cdots + ( italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ© , italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) divide start_ARG italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG [ italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Œ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Œ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j italic_y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] + ‚ãØ (39)

where Œ• 1 = 1 2 ( ‚àÇ 2 p ‚àÇ œµ 2 ) n subscript Œ• 1 1 2 subscript superscript 2 ùëù superscript italic-œµ 2 ùëõ \Upsilon_{1}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\partial^{2}p}{\partial\epsilon^{2}}\right)_{n} roman_Œ• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( divide start_ARG ‚àÇ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_œµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , Œ• 2 = 1 2 ( ‚àÇ 2 p ‚àÇ n 2 ) œµ subscript Œ• 2 1 2 subscript superscript 2 ùëù superscript ùëõ 2 italic-œµ \Upsilon_{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\partial^{2}p}{\partial n^{2}}\right)_{\epsilon} roman_Œ• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( divide start_ARG ‚àÇ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . We have dropped nonlinear terms involving any derivatives, denoted by the ‚ãØ ‚ãØ \cdots ‚ãØ , as their contribution in the hydrodynamic limit œâ ‚Üí 0 , ùê§ ‚Üí 0 formulae-sequence ‚Üí ùúî 0 ‚Üí ùê§ 0 \omega\rightarrow 0,{\bf k}\rightarrow 0 italic_œâ ‚Üí 0 , bold_k ‚Üí 0 will be subleading as compared to the leading terms above. Terms higher than quadratic will not be relevant for the computation of the long-time tails, as we discuss below.

Before we proceed to calculate the long-time tails for the cases of interest, let us intuitively explain their origin from the nonlinear interaction terms in hydrodynamic constitutive relations. Suppose we are interested in computing the effects that follow from quadratic fluctuation terms present in the nonlinear constitutive relation for a given conserved current ùí• ùí• \mathcal{J} caligraphic_J . For concreteness, let us assume that the constitutive relation has the generic form ùí• q u a d ‚àº Œ¶ 1 Œ¶ 2 similar-to subscript ùí• ùëû ùë¢ ùëé ùëë subscript Œ¶ 1 subscript Œ¶ 2 \mathcal{J}_{quad}\sim\Phi_{1}\Phi_{2} caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q italic_u italic_a italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àº roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , where Œ¶ 1 subscript Œ¶ 1 \Phi_{1} roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Œ¶ 2 subscript Œ¶ 2 \Phi_{2} roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are two fluctuating hydrodynamic degrees of freedom. Then the symmetric two-point correlation function of ùí• ùí• \mathcal{J} caligraphic_J receives a nontrivial contribution from the quadratic fluctuation terms, given by

G ùí• ùí• int ( t , ùê± ) ‚àº ‚ü® Œ¶ 1 ( t , ùê± ) Œ¶ 2 ( t , ùê± ) Œ¶ 1 ( 0 ) Œ¶ 2 ( 0 ) ‚ü© . similar-to subscript superscript G int ùí• ùí• ùë° ùê± delimited-‚ü®‚ü© subscript Œ¶ 1 ùë° ùê± subscript Œ¶ 2 ùë° ùê± subscript Œ¶ 1 0 subscript Œ¶ 2 0 {\rm G}^{\rm int}_{\mathcal{J}\mathcal{J}}(t,{\bf x})\sim\langle\Phi_{1}(t,{\bf x})\Phi_{2}(t,{\bf x})\Phi_{1}(0)\Phi_{2}(0)\rangle. roman_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_int end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_J caligraphic_J end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t , bold_x ) ‚àº ‚ü® roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t , bold_x ) roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t , bold_x ) roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) ‚ü© . (40)

Now assuming that the small fluctuations about the state of equilibrium are Gaussian in nature, the four-point correlation function above factorizes into a product of two two-point correlation functions, and is given by

G ùí• ùí• int ( œâ , ùê§ ) ‚àº ‚à´ d œâ ‚Ä≤ 2 œÄ d 3 k ‚Ä≤ ( 2 œÄ ) 3 ùîæ Œ¶ 1 Œ¶ 1 sym ( œâ ‚Ä≤ , ùê§ ‚Ä≤ ) ùîæ Œ¶ 2 Œ¶ 2 sym ( œâ ‚àí œâ ‚Ä≤ , ùê§ ‚àí ùê§ ‚Ä≤ ) , similar-to subscript superscript G int ùí• ùí• ùúî ùê§ ùëë superscript ùúî ‚Ä≤ 2 ùúã superscript ùëë 3 superscript ùëò ‚Ä≤ superscript 2 ùúã 3 subscript superscript ùîæ sym subscript Œ¶ 1 subscript Œ¶ 1 superscript ùúî ‚Ä≤ superscript ùê§ ‚Ä≤ subscript superscript ùîæ sym subscript Œ¶ 2 subscript Œ¶ 2 ùúî superscript ùúî ‚Ä≤ ùê§ superscript ùê§ ‚Ä≤ {\rm G}^{\rm int}_{\mathcal{J}\mathcal{J}}(\omega,{\bf k})\sim\int\frac{d\omega^{\prime}}{2\pi}\frac{d^{3}k^{\prime}}{(2\pi)^{3}}\,\mathbb{G}^{\rm sym}_{\Phi_{1}\Phi_{1}}(\omega^{\prime},{\bf k}^{\prime})\,\mathbb{G}^{\rm sym}_{\Phi_{2}\Phi_{2}}(\omega-\omega^{\prime},{\bf k}-{\bf k}^{\prime})\,, roman_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_int end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_J caligraphic_J end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ , bold_k ) ‚àº ‚à´ divide start_ARG italic_d italic_œâ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_œÄ end_ARG divide start_ARG italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ( 2 italic_œÄ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG blackboard_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_sym end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) blackboard_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_sym end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ¶ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ - italic_œâ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_k - bold_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (41)

where ùîæ ùí™ 1 ùí™ 2 sym subscript superscript ùîæ sym subscript ùí™ 1 subscript ùí™ 2 \mathbb{G}^{\rm sym}_{\mathcal{O}_{1}\mathcal{O}_{2}} blackboard_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_sym end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the symmetric two-point correlation function that follows from linear response theory. These can be computed from the retarded two-point correlators of section 4 by using the fluctuation-dissipation relation,

ùîæ ùí™ 1 ùí™ 2 Sym ( œâ , ùê§ ) = ‚àí 2 T 0 œâ Im ùîæ ùí™ 1 ùí™ 2 Ret ( œâ , ùê§ ) . subscript superscript ùîæ Sym subscript ùí™ 1 subscript ùí™ 2 ùúî ùê§ 2 subscript ùëá 0 ùúî Im subscript superscript ùîæ Ret subscript ùí™ 1 subscript ùí™ 2 ùúî ùê§ \mathbb{G}^{\rm Sym}_{\mathcal{O}_{1}\mathcal{O}_{2}}(\omega,{\bf k})=-\frac{2T_{0}}{\omega}\,{\rm Im}\,\mathbb{G}^{\rm Ret}_{\mathcal{O}_{1}\mathcal{O}_{2}}(\omega,{\bf k}). blackboard_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Sym end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ , bold_k ) = - divide start_ARG 2 italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_œâ end_ARG roman_Im blackboard_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Ret end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ , bold_k ) . (42)

Now the integral in eq.¬†( 41 ) is essentially a one-loop integral, as depicted in the diagram below.

It is the evaluation of this one-loop integral that results into the non-analytic long-time tails in the ùí• ùí• ùí• ùí• \mathcal{J}\mathcal{J} caligraphic_J caligraphic_J two-point function, as we will explore now for the stress tensor correlation functions in our system.

5.1 Long-time tails in stress tensor correlators

With the retarded correlation functions known for the two cases Œ∑ ‚à• ‚â† 0 subscript ùúÇ parallel-to 0 \eta_{\parallel}\neq 0 italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â† 0 and Œ∂ 1 ‚â† 0 subscript ùúÅ 1 0 \zeta_{1}\neq 0 italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â† 0 , it is straight forward to compute the long-time tails in stress tensor two-point functions using the general methodology outlined above. Consider first the case of Œ∑ ‚à• ‚â† 0 subscript ùúÇ parallel-to 0 \eta_{\parallel}\neq 0 italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â† 0 . As a consequence of the nonlinear interaction terms in eq.¬†( 39 ), we get the following contribution to the symmetric two-point function of the T x z superscript ùëá ùë• ùëß T^{xz} italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x italic_z end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT component of the stress tensor, eq.¬†( 40 ),

G T x z T x z int ( t , ùê± ) = Œ∫ 2 ‚ü® œÄ x ( t , ùê± ) œÄ z ( t , ùê± ) œÄ x ( 0 ) œÄ z ( 0 ) ‚ü© , subscript superscript G int superscript ùëá ùë• ùëß superscript ùëá ùë• ùëß ùë° ùê± superscript ùúÖ 2 delimited-‚ü®‚ü© subscript ùúã ùë• ùë° ùê± subscript ùúã ùëß ùë° ùê± subscript ùúã ùë• 0 subscript ùúã ùëß 0 {\rm G}^{\rm int}_{T^{xz}T^{xz}}(t,{\bf x})=\kappa^{2}\langle\pi_{x}(t,{\bf x})\pi_{z}(t,{\bf x})\pi_{x}(0)\pi_{z}(0)\rangle, roman_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_int end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x italic_z end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x italic_z end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t , bold_x ) = italic_Œ∫ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ü® italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t , bold_x ) italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t , bold_x ) italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) ‚ü© , (43)

where

Œ∫ = 1 w 0 2 ( w 0 ‚àí M Œ© , Œº B 0 2 ) . ùúÖ 1 superscript subscript ùë§ 0 2 subscript ùë§ 0 subscript ùëÄ Œ© ùúá superscript subscript ùêµ 0 2 \kappa=\frac{1}{w_{0}^{2}}\left(w_{0}-M_{\Omega,\mu}B_{0}^{2}\right). italic_Œ∫ = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ© , italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (44)

The assumption of Gaussianity for the fluctuations then leads to

ùê§ superscript ùê§ ‚Ä≤ {\rm G}^{\rm int}_{T^{xz}T^{xz}}(\omega,{\bf k})=\kappa^{2}\int\frac{d\omega^{\prime}}{2\pi}\frac{d^{3}k^{\prime}}{(2\pi)^{3}}\,\mathbb{G}^{\rm end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG blackboard_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Sym end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT (45)

Putting in the symmetric correlators in eq.¬†( 45 ) that follow from the retarded two-point functions eqs.¬†( 36a ) and ( 36c ) by the use of the fluctuation-dissipation relation eq.¬†( 42 ), and performing the integrals leads to

G T x z T x z int ( œâ , ùê§ ) = Œ∫ 2 T 0 2 w 0 7 / 2 4 œÄ Œ∑ ‚à• 3 / 2 ( Coth ‚àí 1 2 2 ‚àí 31 30 ) | œâ | + ‚ãØ subscript superscript G int superscript ùëá ùë• ùëß superscript ùëá ùë• ùëß ùúî ùê§ superscript ùúÖ 2 superscript subscript ùëá 0 2 superscript subscript ùë§ 0 7 2 4 ùúã superscript subscript ùúÇ parallel-to 3 2 superscript Coth 1 2 2 31 30 ùúî ‚ãØ {\rm G}^{\rm int}_{T^{xz}T^{xz}}(\omega,{\bf k})=\frac{\kappa^{2}T_{0}^{2}w_{0}^{7/2}}{4\pi\eta_{\parallel}^{3/2}}\left(\frac{{\rm Coth}^{-1}\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{2}}-\frac{31}{30}\right)\sqrt{|\omega|}+\cdots roman_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_int end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x italic_z end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x italic_z end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ , bold_k ) = divide start_ARG italic_Œ∫ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 7 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 4 italic_œÄ italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( divide start_ARG roman_Coth start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG - divide start_ARG 31 end_ARG start_ARG 30 end_ARG ) square-root start_ARG | italic_œâ | end_ARG + ‚ãØ (46)

The appearance of the non-analytic term proportional to | œâ | ùúî \sqrt{|\omega|} square-root start_ARG | italic_œâ | end_ARG is the long-time tail we were interested in finding out. If we Fourier transform the above expression to real time, then we indeed obtain a long-time power-law tail in the two-point function, proportional to | t | ‚àí 3 / 2 superscript ùë° 3 2 |t|^{-3/2} | italic_t | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . This indicates that after sufficiently long time the two-point correlation function does not die off exponentially rapidly, as would be the case if there were no interactions present, but rather falls off as a power-law.

Similarly, for the case when only Œ∂ 1 ‚â† 0 subscript ùúÅ 1 0 \zeta_{1}\neq 0 italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â† 0 , the same stress tensor two-point function receives the non-analytic contribution

G T x z T x z int ( œâ , ùê§ ) = Œ∫ 2 T 0 2 w 0 7 / 2 80 œÄ Œ∂ 1 3 / 2 | œâ | + ‚ãØ subscript superscript G int superscript ùëá ùë• ùëß superscript ùëá ùë• ùëß ùúî ùê§ superscript ùúÖ 2 superscript subscript ùëá 0 2 superscript subscript ùë§ 0 7 2 80 ùúã superscript subscript ùúÅ 1 3 2 ùúî ‚ãØ {\rm G}^{\rm int}_{T^{xz}T^{xz}}(\omega,{\bf k})=\frac{\kappa^{2}T_{0}^{2}w_{0}^{7/2}}{80\pi\zeta_{1}^{3/2}}\sqrt{|\omega|}+\cdots roman_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_int end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x italic_z end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x italic_z end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_œâ , bold_k ) = divide start_ARG italic_Œ∫ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 7 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 80 italic_œÄ italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG square-root start_ARG | italic_œâ | end_ARG + ‚ãØ (47)

which is the long-time tail we were after. One can similarly compute the tails in correlation functions of other components of the stress tensor, and verify that the non-analytic structure present in eqs.¬† ( 46 ) and ( 47 ) persists. Note that the leading corrections in the presence of the magnetic field are proportional to M Œ© , Œº B 0 2 subscript ùëÄ Œ© ùúá superscript subscript ùêµ 0 2 M_{\Omega,\mu}B_{0}^{2} italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ© , italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for the stress tensor correlators considered above. For other correlators, the leading dependence on the magnetic field will similarly follow from eq.¬†( 39 ), as well as from the terms in the linearized equations in A .

Another important point to stress is that even though we set up our calculations in the thermodynamic frame, the final results for the long-time tails are independent of this choice. It is so because physically measurable quantities such as the stress tensor are frame invariant objects, and therefore their correlation functions are frame invariant too.

The non-analytic dependence on œâ ùúî \omega italic_œâ computed in eqs.¬†( 46 ) and ( 47 ) above is for the symmetric correlation functions of stress tensor components. Following the fluctuation-dissipation relation eq.¬†( 42 ), this implies that the retarded correlation functions of the stress tensor will have a non-analytic dependence which behaves as | œâ | 3 / 2 superscript ùúî 3 2 |\omega|^{3/2} | italic_œâ | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . It is the retarded correlation functions which capture the causal response of a system to perturbations, and can be computed by varying the hydrodynamic constitutive relations for the conserved currents with respect to the external sources. Now, in a linearized analysis of fluctuations about a given equilibrium state, one would conclude that the retarded correlators of conserved currents in the limit ùê§ ‚Üí ùüé ‚Üí ùê§ 0 \bf{k}\rightarrow 0 bold_k ‚Üí bold_0 will have a leading behaviour proportional to œâ ùúî \omega italic_œâ , coming from one-derivative terms. This would be followed by a subleading term proportional to œâ 2 superscript ùúî 2 \omega^{2} italic_œâ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that comes from two-derivative terms in the hydrodynamic derivative expansion. However, as we saw above, the presence of nonlinear interaction terms actually contributes a term proportional to | œâ | 3 / 2 superscript ùúî 3 2 |\omega|^{3/2} | italic_œâ | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to the retarded correlator, which is more significant than the terms that come from the second order in the hydrodynamic derivative expansion. We are thus lead to include the effects of nonlinear interaction terms before considering higher derivative terms in the derivative expansion.

Note that the one-loop integral present in the frequency-momentum integrals of eq.¬†( 41 ) is in general UV divergent. We have regulated this divergence by introducing a UV cutoff Œõ Œõ \Lambda roman_Œõ in our computations. These cutoff dependent terms have been suppressed in eqs.¬†( 46 ) and ( 47 ), to focus on the cutoff independent long-time tails in the correlation functions. The cutoff dependence can be absorbed in the renormalization of the associated transport parameters.

6 Discussion

In this paper, we studied fluctuations in a relativistic fluid with a conserved global U ( 1 ) ùëà 1 U(1) italic_U ( 1 ) current in the presence of a background magnetic field, and wrote down the most general linearized hydrodynamic equations for the fluctuations in energy density, charge density and momentum density about a state of global thermal equilibrium (see A ). The background magnetic field renders the setup anisotropic, which results into several new transport parameters. If there were no anisotropy, there would be three dissipative transport parameters at the first-order in the derivative expansion: the shear viscosity Œ∑ ùúÇ \eta italic_Œ∑ , the bulk viscosity Œ∂ ùúÅ \zeta italic_Œ∂ , and the conductivity œÉ ùúé \sigma italic_œÉ . However, the anisotropic background leads to seven dissipative transport parameters in place of three. These are the two shear viscosities Œ∑ ‚à• , Œ∑ ‚üÇ subscript ùúÇ parallel-to subscript ùúÇ perpendicular-to \eta_{\parallel},\eta_{\perp} italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , four bulk viscosities Œ∂ 1 , Œ∂ 2 , Œ∑ 1 , Œ∑ 2 subscript ùúÅ 1 subscript ùúÅ 2 subscript ùúÇ 1 subscript ùúÇ 2 \zeta_{1},\zeta_{2},\eta_{1},\eta_{2} italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , and two conductivities œÉ ‚à• , œÉ ‚üÇ subscript ùúé parallel-to subscript ùúé perpendicular-to \sigma_{\parallel},\sigma_{\perp} italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . Only three of the four bulk viscosities are independent due to the Onsager relation that provides a linear condition between three of them. In addition, there are three first-order non-dissipative transport parameters: the Hall conductivity œÉ ~ ~ ùúé \tilde{\sigma} over~ start_ARG italic_œÉ end_ARG , and the Hall viscosities Œ∑ ~ ‚à• , Œ∑ ~ ‚üÇ subscript ~ ùúÇ parallel-to subscript ~ ùúÇ perpendicular-to \tilde{\eta}_{\parallel},\tilde{\eta}_{\perp} over~ start_ARG italic_Œ∑ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over~ start_ARG italic_Œ∑ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

With the full set of linearized equations in hand, we were able to focus on different subsectors of transport in the system, in each of which one of the transport parameters dominates over the rest. We in particular focused on two cases, when the shear viscosity Œ∑ ‚à• ‚â† 0 subscript ùúÇ parallel-to 0 \eta_{\parallel}\neq 0 italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â† 0 and when the bulk viscosity Œ∂ 1 ‚â† 0 subscript ùúÅ 1 0 \zeta_{1}\neq 0 italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â† 0 . In these two subsectors, we computed the retarded two-point correlation functions of the hydrodynamic fluctuations under suitable simplifying assumptions. Further, with the retarded correlators in hand, we went on to compute the effects of nonlinear interaction terms in the hydrodynamic constitutive relations on the correlation functions of the stress tensor for the fluid. We found the appearance of non-analytic long-time tails in these correlation functions, which lead to power-law fall off for the stress tensor correlation functions after long times, as opposed to an exponential decay.

Several comments are in order. To maintain analytical control we focused on transport in sectors where one of the transport parameters is non-zero, and the rest can be set to vanish. For the purpose of applications to QGP and other physical situations such as dense quark matter in magnetic fields, it would be useful to consider transport when several of the transport parameters are non-zero. This would require a sophisticated numerical approach, which we leave out for a future work. In particular, with applications to QGP in mind, a logical next step is to develop the formalism and compute the long-time non-analytic behaviour when the magnetic field is dynamical i.e. to make use of the full formalism of relativistic magnetohydrodynamics Hernandez:2017mch , which can also be done in the dual formulation in terms of generalized global symmetries Grozdanov:2016tdf . Another possible future direction would be to study the long-time tails in the presence of a magnetic field about a state where the fluid is undergoing longitudinal boost invariant expansion, known as Bjorken flow Martinez:2018wia . Finally, it would also be interesting to understand the non-analytic long-time tails in the presence of a magnetic field from a holographic perspective CaronHuot:2009iq ; Gursoy:2020kjd . We hope to report on some of these directions in the near future.

Appendix A The full set of linearized equations

In this appendix, we present the complete set of linearized hydrodynamic equations about the equilibrium state with temperature T 0 subscript ùëá 0 T_{0} italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , chemical potential Œº 0 subscript ùúá 0 \mu_{0} italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , energy density œµ 0 subscript italic-œµ 0 \epsilon_{0} italic_œµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , pressure p 0 subscript ùëù 0 p_{0} italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and fluid velocity u 0 Œº = ( 1 , ùüé ) subscript superscript ùë¢ ùúá 0 1 0 u^{\mu}_{0}=(1,{\bf 0}) italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 , bold_0 ) . The magnetic field is assumed to be in the + Z ùëç +Z + italic_Z -direction with magnitude B 0 subscript ùêµ 0 B_{0} italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . The equations are written focusing on the genuine transport parameters that appear at first order in the derivative expansion in an out-of-equilibrium state, ignoring the effects from the static susceptibilities such as Œ± BB subscript ùõº BB \alpha_{\rm BB} italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_BB end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , M Œ© subscript ùëÄ Œ© M_{\Omega} italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Œ© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT etc.¬†as their effects become subleading when the system is dominated by fluctuations. The equations take the following form, with the fluctuations Fourier transformed i.e. Œ¥ œµ ( t , ùê± ) = Œ¥ œµ ( t ) e i ùê§ ‚ãÖ ùê± ùõø italic-œµ ùë° ùê± ùõø italic-œµ ùë° superscript ùëí ‚ãÖ ùëñ ùê§ ùê± \delta\epsilon(t,{\bf x})=\delta\epsilon(t)\,e^{i{\bf k}\cdot{\bf x}} italic_Œ¥ italic_œµ ( italic_t , bold_x ) = italic_Œ¥ italic_œµ ( italic_t ) italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i bold_k ‚ãÖ bold_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , and so on.

+ 1 w 0 [ Œ∂ 1 + Œ∂ 2 + Œ∑ ‚à• ‚àí 1 3 ( Œ∑ 1 + Œ∑ 2 ) ] k x k z œÄ z ‚àí Œ∑ ~ ‚à• 2 w 0 k y k z œÄ z 1 subscript ùë§ 0 delimited-[] subscript ùúÅ 1 subscript ùúÅ 2 subscript ùúÇ parallel-to 1 3 subscript ùúÇ 1 subscript ùúÇ 2 subscript ùëò ùë• subscript ùëò ùëß subscript ùúã ùëß subscript ~ ùúÇ parallel-to 2 subscript ùë§ 0 subscript ùëò ùë¶ subscript ùëò ùëß subscript ùúã ùëß \displaystyle\qquad+\frac{1}{w_{0}}\left[\zeta_{1}+\zeta_{2}+\eta_{\parallel}-\textstyle{\frac{1}{3}}(\eta_{1}+\eta_{2})\right]k_{x}k_{z}\pi_{z}-\frac{\tilde{\eta}_{\parallel}}{2w_{0}}k_{y}k_{z}\pi_{z} + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG [ italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ( italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_Œ∑ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
+ i [ ( ( ‚àÇ P ‚àÇ n ) œµ + B 0 Œ± 2 œÉ ~ ) k x + B 0 Œ± 2 œÉ ‚üÇ k y ] Œ¥ n + i [ ( ‚àÇ P ‚àÇ œµ ) n k x + B 0 Œ± 1 ( k x œÉ ~ + k y œÉ ‚üÇ ) ] Œ¥ œµ = 0 , ùëñ delimited-[] subscript ùëÉ ùëõ italic-œµ subscript ùêµ 0 subscript ùõº 2 ~ ùúé subscript ùëò ùë• subscript ùêµ 0 subscript ùõº 2 subscript ùúé perpendicular-to subscript ùëò ùë¶ ùõø ùëõ ùëñ delimited-[] subscript ùëÉ italic-œµ ùëõ subscript ùëò ùë• subscript ùêµ 0 subscript ùõº 1 subscript ùëò ùë• ~ ùúé subscript ùëò ùë¶ subscript ùúé perpendicular-to ùõø italic-œµ 0 \displaystyle\qquad+i\left[\left(\textstyle{\left(\frac{\partial P}{\partial n}\right)_{\epsilon}}+B_{0}\alpha_{2}\tilde{\sigma}\right)k_{x}+B_{0}\alpha_{2}\sigma_{\perp}k_{y}\right]\delta n+i\left[\textstyle{\left(\frac{\partial P}{\partial\epsilon}\right)_{n}}k_{x}+B_{0}\alpha_{1}(k_{x}\tilde{\sigma}+k_{y}\sigma_{\perp})\right]\delta\epsilon=0\,, + italic_i [ ( ( divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_P end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_n end_ARG ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_œÉ end_ARG ) italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] italic_Œ¥ italic_n + italic_i [ ( divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_P end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_œµ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_œÉ end_ARG + italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] italic_Œ¥ italic_œµ = 0 , (50)

+ 1 w 0 [ ( Œ∂ 1 + Œ∑ ‚à• + 2 3 Œ∑ 1 ) k y ‚àí 1 2 Œ∑ ~ ‚à• k x ] k z œÄ y + i ( ‚àÇ P ‚àÇ n ) œµ k z Œ¥ n + i ( ‚àÇ P ‚àÇ œµ ) n k z Œ¥ œµ = 0 , 1 subscript ùë§ 0 delimited-[] subscript ùúÅ 1 subscript ùúÇ parallel-to 2 3 subscript ùúÇ 1 subscript ùëò ùë¶ 1 2 subscript ~ ùúÇ parallel-to subscript ùëò ùë• subscript ùëò ùëß subscript ùúã ùë¶ ùëñ subscript ùëÉ ùëõ italic-œµ subscript ùëò ùëß ùõø ùëõ ùëñ subscript ùëÉ italic-œµ ùëõ subscript ùëò ùëß ùõø italic-œµ 0 \displaystyle\qquad+\frac{1}{w_{0}}\left[(\zeta_{1}+\eta_{\parallel}+\textstyle{\frac{2}{3}}\eta_{1})k_{y}-\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}}\tilde{\eta}_{\parallel}k_{x}\right]k_{z}\pi_{y}+i\textstyle{\left(\frac{\partial P}{\partial n}\right)_{\epsilon}}k_{z}\delta n+i\textstyle{\left(\frac{\partial P}{\partial\epsilon}\right)_{n}}k_{z}\delta\epsilon=0\,, + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG [ ( italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_Œ∑ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_i ( divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_P end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_n end_ARG ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ¥ italic_n + italic_i ( divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_P end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_œµ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ¥ italic_œµ = 0 , (52)

with

Œ± 1 = ( ‚àÇ Œº ‚àÇ œµ ) n ‚àí Œº T ( ‚àÇ T ‚àÇ œµ ) n , subscript ùõº 1 subscript ùúá italic-œµ ùëõ ùúá ùëá subscript ùëá italic-œµ ùëõ \alpha_{1}=\left(\frac{\partial\mu}{\partial\epsilon}\right)_{n}-\frac{\mu}{T}\left(\frac{\partial T}{\partial\epsilon}\right)_{n}, italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_Œº end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_œµ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_Œº end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ( divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_T end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_œµ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

and

Œ± 2 = ( ‚àÇ Œº ‚àÇ n ) œµ ‚àí Œº T ( ‚àÇ T ‚àÇ n ) œµ . subscript ùõº 2 subscript ùúá ùëõ italic-œµ ùúá ùëá subscript ùëá ùëõ italic-œµ \alpha_{2}=\left(\frac{\partial\mu}{\partial n}\right)_{\epsilon}-\frac{\mu}{T}\left(\frac{\partial T}{\partial n}\right)_{\epsilon}. italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_Œº end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_n end_ARG ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_Œº end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ( divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_T end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_n end_ARG ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

It is straightforward to compute the eigenmodes of small oscillations about the chosen equilibrium state, using the linearized equations above. One gets five eigenmodes, of which two are gapped, given by

œâ = ¬± B 0 n 0 w 0 ‚àí i B 0 2 w 0 ( œÉ ‚üÇ ¬± i œÉ ~ ) + ùí™ ( ùê§ 2 ) , ùúî plus-or-minus subscript ùêµ 0 subscript ùëõ 0 subscript ùë§ 0 ùëñ superscript subscript ùêµ 0 2 subscript ùë§ 0 plus-or-minus subscript ùúé perpendicular-to ùëñ ~ ùúé ùí™ superscript ùê§ 2 \omega=\pm\frac{B_{0}n_{0}}{w_{0}}-\frac{iB_{0}^{2}}{w_{0}}\left(\sigma_{\perp}\pm i\tilde{\sigma}\right)+\mathcal{O}({\bf k}^{2}), italic_œâ = ¬± divide start_ARG italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG - divide start_ARG italic_i italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ( italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ¬± italic_i over~ start_ARG italic_œÉ end_ARG ) + caligraphic_O ( bold_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (53)

while the other three are gapless. For ùê§ ‚à• ùêÅ conditional ùê§ ùêÅ {\bf k}\parallel{\bf B} bold_k ‚à• bold_B , the three gapless modes are two sound waves and one diffusive mode, given by

œâ = ¬± k v s ‚àí i 2 Œì ‚à• ùê§ 2 , ùúî plus-or-minus ùëò subscript ùë£ ùë† ùëñ 2 subscript Œì parallel-to superscript ùê§ 2 \displaystyle\omega=\pm kv_{s}-\frac{i}{2}\Gamma_{\parallel}{\bf k}^{2}\,, italic_œâ = ¬± italic_k italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_i end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (54a)
œâ = ‚àí i D ‚à• ùê§ 2 , ùúî ùëñ subscript ùê∑ parallel-to superscript ùê§ 2 \displaystyle\omega=-iD_{\parallel}{\bf k}^{2}\,, italic_œâ = - italic_i italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (54b)

where the speed of sound is given by

v s 2 = ( ‚àÇ p ‚àÇ œµ ) n + n 0 w 0 ( ‚àÇ p ‚àÇ n ) œµ superscript subscript ùë£ ùë† 2 subscript ùëù italic-œµ ùëõ subscript ùëõ 0 subscript ùë§ 0 subscript ùëù ùëõ italic-œµ v_{s}^{2}=\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial\epsilon}\right)_{n}+\frac{n_{0}}{w_{0}}\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial n}\right)_{\epsilon} italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_p end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_œµ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ( divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_p end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_n end_ARG ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

and

Œì ‚à• = 1 w 0 ( Œ∂ 1 + Œ∂ 2 + 2 3 ( Œ∑ 1 + Œ∑ 2 ) ) + 1 v s 2 ( ‚àÇ p ‚àÇ n ) œµ ( Œ± 1 + n 0 w 0 Œ± 2 ) œÉ ‚à• , D ‚à• = 1 v s 2 ( ( ‚àÇ p ‚àÇ œµ ) n Œ± 2 ‚àí ( ‚àÇ p ‚àÇ n ) œµ Œ± 1 ) œÉ ‚à• . \begin{split}&\Gamma_{\parallel}=\frac{1}{w_{0}}\left(\zeta_{1}+\zeta_{2}+\frac{2}{3}\left(\eta_{1}+\eta_{2}\right)\right)+\frac{1}{v_{s}^{2}}\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial
