start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . end_CELL end_ROW

For ùê§ ‚üÇ ùêÅ perpendicular-to ùê§ ùêÅ {\bf k}\perp{\bf B} bold_k ‚üÇ bold_B , the gapless modes consist of one diffusive, one shear and one sub-shear mode, given by

œâ = ‚àí i D ‚üÇ ùê§ 2 , ùúî ùëñ subscript ùê∑ perpendicular-to superscript ùê§ 2 \displaystyle\omega=-iD_{\perp}{\bf k}^{2}\,, italic_œâ = - italic_i italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (55a)
œâ = ‚àí i Œ∑ ‚à• w 0 ùê§ 2 , ùúî ùëñ subscript ùúÇ parallel-to subscript ùë§ 0 superscript ùê§ 2 \displaystyle\omega=-i\frac{\eta_{\parallel}}{w_{0}}{\bf k}^{2}\,, italic_œâ = - italic_i divide start_ARG italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG bold_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (55b)
œâ = ‚àí i Œì ‚üÇ ( ùê§ 2 ) 2 , ùúî ùëñ subscript Œì perpendicular-to superscript superscript ùê§ 2 2 \displaystyle\omega=-i\Gamma_{\perp}({\bf k}^{2})^{2}\,, italic_œâ = - italic_i roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (55c)

where

D ‚üÇ = w 0 ( ( ‚àÇ p ‚àÇ œµ ) n ‚àí n 0 Œ± 1 ) œÉ ‚üÇ B 0 2 œÉ ‚üÇ 2 + ( n 0 + B 0 œÉ ~ ) 2 , Œì ‚üÇ = ( ( ‚àÇ p ‚àÇ œµ ) n Œ± 2 ‚àí ( ‚àÇ p ‚àÇ n ) œµ Œ± 1 ) Œ∑ ‚üÇ B 0 2 ( ( ‚àÇ p ‚àÇ œµ ) n ‚àí n 0 Œ± 1 ) . formulae-sequence subscript ùê∑ perpendicular-to subscript ùë§ 0 subscript ùëù italic-œµ ùëõ subscript ùëõ 0 subscript ùõº 1 subscript ùúé perpendicular-to superscript subscript ùêµ 0 2 superscript subscript ùúé perpendicular-to 2 superscript subscript ùëõ 0 subscript ùêµ 0 ~ ùúé 2 subscript Œì perpendicular-to subscript ùëù italic-œµ ùëõ subscript ùõº 2 subscript ùëù ùëõ italic-œµ subscript ùõº 1 subscript ùúÇ perpendicular-to superscript subscript ùêµ 0 2 subscript ùëù italic-œµ ùëõ subscript ùëõ 0 subscript ùõº 1 \begin{split}&D_{\perp}=\frac{w_{0}\left(\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial\epsilon}\right)_{n}-n_{0}\alpha_{1}\right)\sigma_{\perp}}{B_{0}^{2}\sigma_{\perp}^{2}+\left(n_{0}+B_{0}\tilde{\sigma}\right)^{2}}\,,\\ &\Gamma_{\perp}=\frac{\left(\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial\epsilon}\right)_{n}\alpha_{2}-\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial n}\right)_{\epsilon}\alpha_{1}\right)\eta_{\perp}}{B_{0}^{2}\left(\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial\epsilon}\right)_{n}-n_{0}\alpha_{1}\right)}.\end{split} start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ( divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_p end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_œµ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ( italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_œÉ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL roman_Œì start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG ( ( divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_p end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_œµ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ( divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_p end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_n end_ARG ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚üÇ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ( divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_p end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_œµ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG . end_CELL end_ROW

In Hernandez:2017mch , the authors study the linearized hydrodynamic equations in terms of the fluctuations Œ¥ T , Œ¥ Œº ùõø ùëá ùõø ùúá \delta T,\delta\mu italic_Œ¥ italic_T , italic_Œ¥ italic_Œº in the temperature and chemical potential. On the other hand, our analysis above works with the fluctuations Œ¥ œµ , Œ¥ n ùõø italic-œµ ùõø ùëõ \delta\epsilon,\delta n italic_Œ¥ italic_œµ , italic_Œ¥ italic_n in the energy and charge density. The two approaches are equivalent, and in particular the modes we have found above are in agreement with the ones reported in Hernandez:2017mch , after an appropriate transformation from derivatives with respect to œµ , n italic-œµ ùëõ \epsilon,n italic_œµ , italic_n to derivatives with respect to Œº , T ùúá ùëá \mu,T italic_Œº , italic_T , which are the independent variables in the grand canonical ensemble.

Appendix B The susceptibility matrix ùùå ùùå \boldsymbol{\chi} bold_italic_œá

In the main text, we focus on two subsectors of the full set of linearized equations in A : first when only Œ∑ ‚à• ‚â† 0 subscript ùúÇ parallel-to 0 \eta_{\parallel}\neq 0 italic_Œ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â† 0 , and second when only Œ∂ 1 ‚â† 0 subscript ùúÅ 1 0 \zeta_{1}\neq 0 italic_Œ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â† 0 . For both the cases we compute the retarded two-point correlation functions of hydrodynamic fluctuations using linear response theory, see 4.1 and 4.2 . For this we need to make use of the susceptibility matrix ùùå ùùå \boldsymbol{\chi} bold_italic_œá defined in eq.¬†( 35 ). This can be computed as follows. The complete set of hydrodynamic fluctuations is

Œ¶ = ( Œ¥ n , Œ¥ œµ , œÄ x , œÄ y , œÄ z ) . Œ¶ ùõø ùëõ ùõø italic-œµ subscript ùúã ùë• subscript ùúã ùë¶ subscript ùúã ùëß \Phi=\left(\delta n,\delta\epsilon,\pi_{x},\pi_{y},\pi_{z}\right). roman_Œ¶ = ( italic_Œ¥ italic_n , italic_Œ¥ italic_œµ , italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (56)

Now the partition function in the grand canonical ensemble is given by

ùíµ = Tr exp ‚Å° [ ‚àí Œ≤ ( H ‚àí Œº N ) ] , ùíµ Tr ùõΩ ùêª ùúá ùëÅ \mathcal{Z}={\rm Tr}\exp\left[-\beta(H-\mu N)\right], caligraphic_Z = roman_Tr roman_exp [ - italic_Œ≤ ( italic_H - italic_Œº italic_N ) ] , (57)

where H ùêª H italic_H is the Hamiltonian and N ùëÅ N italic_N is the total charge. Under infinitesimal variations Œ¥ T , Œ¥ Œº ùõø ùëá ùõø ùúá \delta T,\delta\mu italic_Œ¥ italic_T , italic_Œ¥ italic_Œº and Œ¥ u i ùõø superscript ùë¢ ùëñ \delta u^{i} italic_Œ¥ italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in temperature, chemical potential and velocity, we get the new partition function to be

ùíµ ‚Ä≤ = Tr exp ‚Å° [ ‚àí Œ≤ ( H ‚àí Œº N ) + Œ¥ T T 2 ( H ‚àí Œº N ) + Œ¥ Œº T N + 1 T Œ¥ ùêÆ ‚ãÖ ùêè ] superscript ùíµ ‚Ä≤ Tr ùõΩ ùêª ùúá ùëÅ ùõø ùëá superscript ùëá 2 ùêª ùúá ùëÅ ùõø ùúá ùëá ùëÅ ‚ãÖ 1 ùëá ùõø ùêÆ ùêè \begin{split}\mathcal{Z}^{\prime}={\rm Tr}&\exp\bigg{[}-\beta(H-\mu N)+\frac{\delta T}{T^{2}}(H-\mu N)+\frac{\delta\mu}{T}N+\frac{1}{T}\,{\bf\delta u}\cdot{\bf P}\bigg{]}\end{split} start_ROW start_CELL caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_Tr end_CELL start_CELL roman_exp [ - italic_Œ≤ ( italic_H - italic_Œº italic_N ) + divide start_ARG italic_Œ¥ italic_T end_ARG start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( italic_H - italic_Œº italic_N ) + divide start_ARG italic_Œ¥ italic_Œº end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG italic_N + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG italic_Œ¥ bold_u ‚ãÖ bold_P ] end_CELL end_ROW (58)

For use in linear response theory, the quantity of interest is the perturbation to the Hamiltonian, which for slowly varying sources can be read off from eq.¬†( 58 ) as

Œ¥ H ( t ) = ‚àí ‚à´ d 3 x ( Œ¥ T ( t , ùê± ) T ( œµ ( t , ùê± ) ‚àí Œº n ( t , ùê± ) ) + Œ¥ Œº ( t , ùê± ) n ( t , ùê± ) + Œ¥ u i ( t , ùê± ) œÄ i ( t , ùê± ) ) . ùõø ùêª ùë° superscript ùëë 3 ùë• ùõø ùëá ùë° ùê± ùëá italic-œµ ùë° ùê± ùúá ùëõ ùë° ùê± ùõø ùúá ùë° ùê± ùëõ ùë° ùê± ùõø superscript ùë¢ ùëñ ùë° ùê± subscript ùúã ùëñ ùë° ùê± \delta H(t)=-\int d^{3}x\bigg{(}\frac{\delta T(t,{\bf x})}{T}(\epsilon(t,{\bf x})-\mu\,n(t,{\bf x}))+\delta\mu(t,{\bf x})\,n(t,{\bf x})+\delta u^{i}(t,{\bf x})\,\pi_{i}(t,{\bf x})\bigg{)}. italic_Œ¥ italic_H ( italic_t ) = - ‚à´ italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x ( divide start_ARG italic_Œ¥ italic_T ( italic_t , bold_x ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ( italic_œµ ( italic_t , bold_x ) - italic_Œº italic_n ( italic_t , bold_x ) ) + italic_Œ¥ italic_Œº ( italic_t , bold_x ) italic_n ( italic_t , bold_x ) + italic_Œ¥ italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t , bold_x ) italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t , bold_x ) ) . (59)

Therefore the sources for the hydrodynamic variables eq.¬†( 56 ) are given by

œï = ( Œ¥ Œº ‚àí Œº T Œ¥ T , Œ¥ T T , Œ¥ u x , Œ¥ u y , Œ¥ u z ) . italic-œï ùõø ùúá ùúá ùëá ùõø ùëá ùõø ùëá ùëá ùõø subscript ùë¢ ùë• ùõø subscript ùë¢ ùë¶ ùõø subscript ùë¢ ùëß \phi=\left(\delta\mu-\frac{\mu}{T}\delta T,\,\frac{\delta T}{T},\,\delta u_{x},\,\delta u_{y},\,\delta u_{z}\right). italic_œï = ( italic_Œ¥ italic_Œº - divide start_ARG italic_Œº end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG italic_Œ¥ italic_T , divide start_ARG italic_Œ¥ italic_T end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG , italic_Œ¥ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œ¥ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œ¥ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (60)

One can now compute the susceptibility matrix eq.¬†( 35 ) by differentiating the hydrodynamic variables in eq.¬†( 56 ) with respect to their sources in eq.¬†( 60 ), keeping in mind that

Œ¥ œµ = ( ‚àÇ œµ ‚àÇ Œº ) T ( Œ¥ Œº ‚àí Œº T Œ¥ T ) + [ Œº ( ‚àÇ œµ ‚àÇ Œº ) T + T ( ‚àÇ œµ ‚àÇ T ) Œº ] Œ¥ T T , ùõø italic-œµ subscript italic-œµ ùúá ùëá ùõø ùúá ùúá ùëá ùõø ùëá delimited-[] ùúá subscript italic-œµ ùúá ùëá ùëá subscript italic-œµ ùëá ùúá ùõø ùëá ùëá \delta\epsilon=\left(\frac{\partial\epsilon}{\partial\mu}\right)_{T}\left(\delta\mu-\frac{\mu}{T}\delta T\right)+\left[\mu\left(\frac{\partial\epsilon}{\partial\mu}\right)_{T}+T\left(\frac{\partial\epsilon}{\partial T}\right)_{\mu}\right]\frac{\delta T}{T}, italic_Œ¥ italic_œµ = ( divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_œµ end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_Œº end_ARG ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ¥ italic_Œº - divide start_ARG italic_Œº end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG italic_Œ¥ italic_T ) + [ italic_Œº ( divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_œµ end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_Œº end_ARG ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_T ( divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_œµ end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_T end_ARG ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] divide start_ARG italic_Œ¥ italic_T end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ,
Œ¥ n = ( ‚àÇ n ‚àÇ Œº ) T ( Œ¥ Œº ‚àí Œº T Œ¥ T ) + [ Œº ( ‚àÇ n ‚àÇ Œº ) T + T ( ‚àÇ n ‚àÇ T ) Œº ] Œ¥ T T , ùõø ùëõ subscript ùëõ ùúá ùëá ùõø ùúá ùúá ùëá ùõø ùëá delimited-[] ùúá subscript ùëõ ùúá ùëá ùëá subscript ùëõ ùëá ùúá ùõø ùëá ùëá \delta n=\left(\frac{\partial n}{\partial\mu}\right)_{T}\left(\delta\mu-\frac{\mu}{T}\delta T\right)+\left[\mu\left(\frac{\partial n}{\partial\mu}\right)_{T}+T\left(\frac{\partial n}{\partial T}\right)_{\mu}\right]\frac{\delta T}{T}, italic_Œ¥ italic_n = ( divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_n end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_Œº end_ARG ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Œ¥ italic_Œº - divide start_ARG italic_Œº end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG italic_Œ¥ italic_T ) + [ italic_Œº ( divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_n end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_Œº end_ARG ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_T ( divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_n end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_T end_ARG ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] divide start_ARG italic_Œ¥ italic_T end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ,

and œÄ i = w 0 Œ¥ u i subscript ùúã ùëñ subscript ùë§ 0 ùõø subscript ùë¢ ùëñ \pi_{i}=w_{0}\,\delta u_{i} italic_œÄ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ¥ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . This gives the susceptibility matrix as

ùùå = ( ( ‚àÇ n ‚àÇ Œº ) T Œº ( ‚àÇ n ‚àÇ Œº ) T + T ( ‚àÇ n ‚àÇ T ) Œº 0 0 0 ( ‚àÇ œµ ‚àÇ Œº ) T Œº ( ‚àÇ œµ ‚àÇ Œº ) T + T ( ‚àÇ œµ ‚àÇ T ) Œº 0 0 0 0 0 w 0 0 0 0 0 0 w 0 0 0 0 0 0 w 0 ) . ùùå For computing the long-time tails, we further specialize to an equilibrium state with Œº 0 = 0 subscript ùúá 0 0 \mu_{0}=0 italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 i.e. the equilibrium charge density vanishes n 0 = 0 subscript ùëõ 0 0 n_{0}=0 italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 . For systems that respect charge conjugation invariance, this further leads to the vanishing of thermodynamic derivatives such as ( ‚àÇ n / ‚àÇ T ) Œº = 0 , ( ‚àÇ œµ / ‚àÇ Œº ) T = 0 formulae-sequence subscript ùëõ ùëá ùúá 0 subscript italic-œµ ùúá ùëá 0 (\partial n/\partial T)_{\mu}=0,(\partial\epsilon/\partial\mu)_{T}=0 ( ‚àÇ italic_n / ‚àÇ italic_T ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œº end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 , ( ‚àÇ italic_œµ / ‚àÇ italic_Œº ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 , since they are proportional to ‚ü® H N ‚ü© conn subscript delimited-‚ü®‚ü© ùêª ùëÅ conn \langle HN\rangle_{\rm conn} ‚ü® italic_H italic_N ‚ü© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_conn end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , which vanishes by charge conjugation invariance. Further ‚àÇ œµ / ‚àÇ T ‚â° c v = w 0 / T v s 2 italic-œµ ùëá subscript ùëê ùë£ subscript ùë§ 0 ùëá superscript subscript ùë£ ùë† 2 \partial\epsilon/\partial T\equiv c_{v}=w_{0}/Tv_{s}^{2} ‚àÇ italic_œµ / ‚àÇ italic_T ‚â° italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_T italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , further simplifying the susceptibility matrix above, which can then be used to compute the retarded correlation functions via eq.¬†( 34 ) in linear response theory.

Acknowledgments

The author would like to thank Pavel Kovtun and Juan Hernandez for very helpful discussions, and for their comments on a draft version of the paper. Research at Perimeter Institute is supported in part by the Government of Canada through the Department of Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada and by the Province of Ontario through the Ministry of Colleges and Universities.
